post_title: â€˜TripAdvisor of the co-working industryâ€™ scores funding
content:
The advertising model requires the coworking space to pay up-front, with no guarantee of ever getting customers.Â Â Commission is a much fairer model, with the aggregator only getting paid when the coworking space does.Â  Â 

End-users hate advertising, and are wary of paid search results, so I find it strange that coworker thinks advertising is a better model than commission.Â  The online marketplaces and travel booking websites learned this lesson years ago.

post_title: Discuss: Is 5 years enough to change the culture in a large organization?
content: For culture change, I find it useful to look at the work of Harvard Kennedy School professor Ronald Heifetz, known for the theory of â€œadaptive leadership.â€Heifetz formerly worked as an emergency room doctor. One night a woman came in, having been badly beaten by her husband. Heifetz patched her up, and she left. A few months later, she came in again, with the same situation. Heifetz patched her up, and sent her out again. A few more months went by, and she came in again for a third time, beaten again. This time, Heifetz asked the woman why it was that she remained in this relationship that was clearly a threat to her safety.Â She responded, â€œgrowing up, my father beat my mother. If I left my husband, I would be sending the message to my parents that I did not approve of their relationship.â€ Heifetz saw in that moment that while he could fix the womanâ€™s wounds, the root of the problem was complex, and only she could solve it herself.The case of the woman illustrates two different kinds of problems that we face in life and business, with two different types of solutions: technical and adaptive. With technical challenges, there is a clear problem with a clear solution. Therefore, the â€œexpertâ€ or â€œleaderâ€ just needs to get the people out of the way so that they can solve it, or direct people to follow their orders. With adaptive challenges, the problem is not always clear, making the solution even less clear. In this case, the people are the problem, but the people are also the solution.For technical challenges, a leader needs to operate like a surgeon, for adaptive ones, they need to operate like a psychologist. When it comes to culture change, it is almost always an adaptive challenge. For tech firms and technical professionals, solving technical problems is usually what theyâ€™re best at, and when it comes to culture change, they sometimes tend to approach that as a technical problem as well, which is a mistake.
excerpt: For culture change, I find it useful to look at the work of Harvard Kennedy School professor Ronald Heifetz, known for the theory of "adaptive leadership."Heifetz formerly worked as an emergency room doctor. One night a woman came in, having been badly beaten by her husband. Heifetz patched her up, and she left. A few months later, she came in again, with the same situation. Heifetz patched her up, and sent her out again. A few more months went by, and she came in again for a third time, beaten again. This time, Heifetz asked the woman why it was that she remained in this relationship that was clearly a threat to her safety.Â She responded, "growing up, my father beat my mother. If I left my husband, I would be sending the message to my parents that I did not approve of their relationship." Heifetz saw in that moment that while he could fix the woman's wounds, the root of the problem was complex, and only she could solve it herself.The case of the woman illustrates two different kinds of problems that we face in life and business, with two different types of solutions: technical and adaptive. With technical challenges, there is a clear problem with a clear solution. Therefore, the "expert" or "leader" just needs to get the people out of the way so that they can solve it, or direct people to follow their orders. With adaptive challenges, the problem is not always clear, making the solution even less clear. In this case, the people are the problem, but the people are also the solution.For technical challenges, a leader needs to operate like a surgeon, for adaptive ones, they need to operate like a psychologist. When it comes to culture change, it is almost always an adaptive challenge. For tech firms and technical professionals, solving technical problems is usually what they're best at, and when it comes to culture change, they sometimes tend to approach that as a technical problem as well, which is a mistake.

post_title: I spoke to 11 people in media and learned how startups can get better media coverage
content:
And something left out of the articleâ€¦

Media coverage is over-hyped and will not be nearly as important to your success as simply driving good relations with your customers/partners and over delivering. So if you have to choose between sucking someoneâ€™s dick in the media for coverage, or spending that time down on the ground with customers â€“ take the customers every time.

Sure, getting on Forbes/etc.. gives a nice spike in interest, but in general real business growth almost always comes slow and steady from consistent focus on the customer and core revenue.

content:
Thanks for this great article Andrew! Sending good content is often overlooked as a sure-fire method to getÂ media coverage.Â In my experience, a lot of bad media relationsÂ comes from an overemphasis on pushing for wide reach ofÂ a mediocre narrative.Â Success is often measured by reach, but not many see that reach as a direct result of the quality of the story.Â 

To build onto that point, itâ€™s important to be open to feedback on your content. Take thoseÂ experiences of successful and failedÂ media pitchesÂ and adjust your approach and your storyÂ based on that. Building goodÂ relationship with the right people (as emphasised in your article)Â is a big part of getting more qualityÂ feedback.Â

content: There is a reasonable argument to be made for broader surveillance methods, but what is perhaps most baffling to me is how little information Tencent gives about what they do with user data. This is a theme across the board with Chinese internet and tech firms as they globalize. The number 1 issue that they face is earning the trust of their users, but many of them behave on ways that seem to actively foster distrust.

post_title: Outside of China, WeChat is a fish out of water
content:
Iâ€™m wondering if, when writing the article, you have taken into account that there are actually two servers used for WeChat/Weixin. Which server routes your messages dependsÂ Â on where you installed the app. When installed in China your messages go through a Chinese server and are prone to censorship, which Tencent has to submit to if they donâ€™t want to lose their license. When installed outside China messages run through an international server. Maybe the information you have been readingÂ is about the international server while the censorship example took place on the Chinese server?

Ed

post_title: Outside of China, WeChat is a fish out of water
content:
I do not agreed with the writer about privacy, a average person living in any country, we should obey the local law, why would a average person bother the the message send or received if it is just a normal message that will not compromise the security of the country,unless the sender intent to spread or promote propaganda that will harm the country stability.

Western country do spy on their citizen too.I have stay in San Jose,Taiwan and Hong Kong for years and now posted to China since 2011 and i am doing fine as i do not send any content online or offline that will harm the stability of the country i live in.

From a security consultant perspective, when we provide consultancy toÂ Financial institutions and MNCsÂ for their ITÂ security policy, we always advice thatÂ Security cannot be compromised, you need to ensure that all employees using theÂ network infrastructure are purely for the business objective of the company.No one are allowed to bring in their own device to connect,as majority of the compromised are done internally.There are many cases where employees send email or content that harm the company goodwill.

There is no such thing as secret in the world of Digital.

post_title: 11 months and $750k later, I closed my drop shipping business. Hereâ€™s why
content:
Thomas, merci beaucoup for your honesty and a really great article! Itâ€™s so refreshing to read content that is so easy and authentic!
The value criteria is essential, I agree, and with so much competition out there, despite all the ads you like, what captivates a Market is the message or impression that you care about their needs and have sourced products that are designed to resolve their problem or provide relief for their frustration etc.
We will be marketing mothers and fathers of children with cognitive disabilities as well as parents involved in divorce. This is a highly specific niche with extremely clear needs- primarily products that will relax and soothe mind and body of both parents and children, home decor and kitchenware that is practical and comfortable- goodies that make life easier.
Am I on the right track? Thankyou, Lisa

post_title: 11 months and $750k later, I closed my drop shipping business. Hereâ€™s why
content: Thomas,Â Great article, appreciate your honesty. Quite frankly, Iâ€™ve been in the dropshipping trenches for a couple months now (no financial success) and Iâ€™m tired of the salesman guru talk of every one who tries to sell me an e-book hah!Iâ€™ve switched niches multiple time because IÂ just lost interest over the long run. Some people need to like what theyâ€™re selling and some people donâ€™t.Â  GuessÂ Iâ€™m the latter â€“ so right now Iâ€™m mixing dropshipping one type of product (with different art prints) while IÂ make the same product in alibaba with my own design â€“ either fulfilling that SKUÂ by myself or having a fulfillment house in the states to do it for me if it makes sense.IÂ think you nailed it on some of the comment replies â€“ find out what works for you and what makes you happy, and do that. Before going niche into something IÂ actually use/wear, IÂ also tried a general store. Testing random products was one of the most boring/lonely/bang-my-head-on-the-wall processes Iâ€™ve ever experienced.

Quite frankly, I've been in the dropshipping trenches for a couple months now (no financial success) and I'm tired of the salesman guru talk of every one who tries to sell me an e-book hah!I've switched niches multiple time because IÂ just lost interest over the long run. Some people need to like what they're selling and some people don't.Â  GuessÂ I'm the latter - so right now I'm mixing dropshipping one type of product (with different art prints) while IÂ make the same product in alibaba with my own design - either fulfilling that SKUÂ by myself or having a fulfillment house in the states to do it for me if it makes sense.IÂ think you nailed it on some of the comment replies - find out what works for you and what makes you happy, and do that. Before going niche into something IÂ actually use/wear, IÂ also tried a general store. Testing random products was one of the most boring/lonely/bang-my-head-on-the-wall processes I've ever experienced.

post_title: 11 months and $750k later, I closed my drop shipping business. Hereâ€™s why
content:
Hi , after reading your article, I feel very impressed with your capability and foremost, your kindness. I truly feel it. As, I myself, who are currently in that situation like you before you founded Drop shipping, would like to give a shot into this no inventory/stocks holding cost, shipping and packing responsibility except, an opportunity to do a business with making a reasonable profit margin. For the past 1 week or so, I had been gathering lots of information over the internet and Facebook drop shipping forum or group chat. I was truly amazed by those budding drop shipping entrepreneur who share their thoughts and experience with me. Beside this and of course, I do read and study many articles posted by Shopify, Aliexspress drop ship, and other potential Ecommerce service providers in my own country, Malaysia as well.Â 

Like you say, only by experiencing the business, we can see the results. Therefore, by not missing the chance, I will take this opportunity to jump in and joined the crowd and hopefully, I can find my pot of gold to overcome my financial circumstances. Thatâ€™s is the only way out. I believed, when 17 doors close for you, you will only need 1 door to be open for you and with the right key. I hope,after reading your inspirational writing, I will have more confidence to take on the challenges and to restart my life. Moreover, success and learning is a journey and not destination. We just have to keep going and going to find ways to unlock our failures. The day will come soon if we have faith, courage and determination to take ACTION.

Therefore, by not missing the chance, I will take this opportunity to jump in and joined the crowd and hopefully, I can find my pot of gold to overcome my financial circumstances. That's is the only way out. I believed, when 17 doors close for you, you will only need 1 door to be open for you and with the right key. content: Highly doubt Softbank will put in any â€œsignificantâ€ amount asÂ part of the 900m still to be closed, unless its investment termsÂ in Uber continues getting pushback from the likes of Benchmark. Forcing user to create an account does not really retain use. Forcing user to do something does not really create the stickiness.

content: Free shipping is huge. My wife and I used to shop in Tokopedia but have started to use Shopee alot in the past few months. It seems alot of sellers are moving to Shopee. I think Shopee is more generous with free shipping, coins and promotions, while I find Tokopedia is stingy and slow. Iâ€™ve had some bad experience with Lazada and comparing prices, Lazada is expensive. So I wonâ€™t be surprised if Shopee were to be #1. But Shopee doesnâ€™t support installments for Indonesiaâ€™s big banks and only have Kredivo. They need to work on supporting 0-3% credit card installments, otherwise I only buy stuff that costs less than $50. Expensive stuff I will always rely on JD.id or maybe Blibli. Best customer service, free shipping and no hassle.

post_title: Salim and Lotte launch new Indonesian ecommerce site with $100m budget
content:
Thereâ€™s already way too many e-commerce websites in Indonesia. Hell, even with the constant TV, billboard, Google and YouTube ad campaigns, I could only name JD.ID, MatahariMall.com, and Shoppee amongst the new ones. None of which IÂ use; I use Lazada, Tokopedia, or BukaLapak. Mostly Lazada or Tokopedia, because the former is just reliable (itâ€™s pretty much the Amazon of Indonesia now, what with its own courier service) and the latter because they tend to be the cheapest.

iLotte is another e-commerce that very few are going to use. Even MatahariMall, with its unique physical stands and delivery to a retrieval locker, is still not very popular because theyâ€™re just too late. Hell, not even Lineâ€™s e-commerce is used much, and Line is very popular among young phone users.Â Lazada, Tokopedia, and BukaLapak has already taken the biggest names when it comes e-commerce. Maybe add Zalora as well, though that one is focused on fashion.

I donâ€™t see iLotte being successful. Certainly not outside of Java.

post_title: Salim and Lotte launch new Indonesian ecommerce site with $100m budget
content:
Indonesians are still kind of distrustful of online commerce of all kind. So I think that theyâ€™re going to be loyal to the one(s) that first gave them a good experience (and be much more wary if that first impression is a bad one, as is often the case with buying fashion and accessories).

Itâ€™s why I think the early pioneer of modern e-commerce sites like Tokopedia and BukaLapak are very successful, they were early, they managed to get a lot of good retailers, and they are reliable in term of usability, service, and delivering. Lazada came later, as IÂ recall, but they have a Pay on Delivery option which I imagine helped win a lot of people. There was also sites like Tokobagus, which lost because it changed its name to OLX (which is much less memorable if you ask me)Â and rather narrow in what they provide. Then there are sites like Bhinneka which failed in marketing and attracting enough users that it cannot start the self-sustaining cycle of customer, retailer, and site size up.

By this point, you need to do a lot of aggressive marketing and even then, thereâ€™s going to be resistance from simple distrust from the rather technologically illiterate older Indonesian to simple preferences of sites youâ€™re used to. The closest comparisons I could bring with iLotte are Alfacart and MatahariMall, and theyâ€™re not thatÂ successful.
excerpt: Indonesians are still kind of distrustful of online commerce of all kind. So I think that they're going to be loyal to the one(s) that first gave them a good experience (and be much more wary if that first impression is a bad one, as is often the case with buying fashion and accessories).It's why I think the early pioneer of modern e-commerce sites like Tokopedia and BukaLapak are very successful, they were early, they managed to get a lot of good retailers, and they are reliable in term of usability, service, and delivering. Lazada came later, as IÂ recall, but they have a Pay on Delivery option which I imagine helped win a lot of people. There was also sites like Tokobagus, which lost because it changed its name to OLX (which is much less memorable if you ask me)Â and rather narrow in what they provide. Then there are sites like Bhinneka which failed in marketing and attracting enough users that it cannot start the self-sustaining cycle of customer, retailer, and site size up.By this point, you need to do a lot of aggressive marketing and even then, there's going to be resistance from simple distrust from the rather technologically illiterate older Indonesian to simple preferences of sites you're used to. The closest comparisons I could bring with iLotte are Alfacart and MatahariMall, and they're not thatÂ successful.

post_title: Discuss: Why the cryptocurrency discussion is going nowhere
content:
In my opinion weâ€™re still debating the value of two things that look the same but are not in use, and today can not be in use, by the same groups of people.

Take an analogy â€“ cloud block storage is great, of high value to specific groups of people (devs and hobbyists) and has seen stunning growth in its niche; Dropbox arguably has similar functionalities (especially with its API) but was designed to be more accessible from the beginning as itâ€™s purpose is slightly different.

Now, I use both cloud block storage and Dropbox, but my mother only uses Dropbox, but not cloud block storage. Her reasons are those of (a) access, (b) utility, and (c) purpose.

Despite how technically beautiful cloud block storage is, she (a) has no idea how to turn it on, (b) no real reason to use it, and (c) no understanding of how this will be better for her than Dropbox.

Similarly, cryptocurrencies are currently the fancy of developers (because of how technically beautiful they are) and hobbyists (financial people that think they understand technology :-p ), but the average fiat currency users lack (a) any ability to buy crypto easily, (b) any real ways to use it beyond investment at this stage, and (c) any understanding of why this is better to *invest* in than gold or tech stocks.

(A) Access

I say access is a problem because the average user is not going to mine the currency. Also, buying bitcoin in most countries requires serious motivation as access is still the same now as it was 4 years ago â€“ you still have to act like a degenerate drug buyer, and meet random suppliers in coffee shops and swap cash. There are a few other ways to get in, but until I can Google my way into using my credit card to buy coin, we should consider access a problem.

(B) Purpose

Why should anyone buy any crypto currency if they canâ€™t spend it anywhere? Or at least cash it out in the same why they do marketÂ  investments? Without any real reason or way to properly use it, it will remain something cool for hobbyists. Also, I can keep getting more of any fiat currency I want very, very easily. You donâ€™t see people in Asia stressing about spending their USD, because they know they can just change and get some more â€“ from their local mall as well!

(C) Utility

My current fiat currency does everything I need it to, my local corner shop understands it, and I can pay for stuff without jumping through hoops. It has clear benefits for me, but the average user canâ€™t see the same thing with crypto currencies.

I believe that if we can crack the access issue â€“ both buying and spending, pretty much everything else can be toppled. It will also bring a level of stability to the environment. I appreciate there is lots of debate about which currency is better, bla bla bla, but realistically everything for the average use boils down to branding. Bitcoin has the best brand today, and the average user has no idea what ethereum is.Â 

I reckon we should be talking in mBTC and working on regulatory compliant methods of access. KYC, AML, and all the other three letter acronyms of governance are a harsh reality of where we are with the world of money. Merge both worlds today so there is a bridge of access â€“ but thatâ€™s exactly what it is, bridge.

Her reasons are those of (a) access, (b) utility, and (c) purpose.Despite how technically beautiful cloud block storage is, she (a) has no idea how to turn it on, (b) no real reason to use it, and (c) no understanding of how this will be better for her than Dropbox.Similarly, cryptocurrencies are currently the fancy of developers (because of how technically beautiful they are) and hobbyists (financial people that think they understand technology :-p ), but the average fiat currency users lack (a) any ability to buy crypto easily, (b) any real ways to use it beyond investment at this stage, and (c) any understanding of why this is better to *invest* in than gold or tech stocks.(A) AccessI say access is a problem because the average user is not going to mine the currency. Also, buying bitcoin in most countries requires serious motivation as access is still the same now as it was 4 years ago â€“ you still have to act like a degenerate drug buyer, and meet random suppliers in coffee shops and swap cash. There are a few other ways to get in, but until I can Google my way into using my credit card to buy coin, we should consider access a problem.(B) PurposeWhy should anyone buy any crypto currency if they canâ€™t spend it anywhere? Merge both worlds today so there is a bridge of access â€“ but thatâ€™s exactly what it is, bridge.

post_title: Discuss: Why the cryptocurrency discussion is going nowhere
content:
Hey Peter: Help me understand a bit moreâ€“ why does this topic bother you? ğŸ™‚ I find yourÂ framing of speculation Vs long term investment interesting.Â Why do we care about why people â€œinvestâ€ in crypto?

In addition, would you defineÂ all cryptos as â€œcurrenciesâ€? The disconnect in debate seems to stem from a failure to agree ontologically. InÂ particular, the definitions of the words â€œsecurityâ€, â€œcurrencyâ€ and â€œinvestmentâ€ are not standardizedÂ when people write aboutÂ cryptocurrency.

At this point I personally would channel energy intoÂ debating how toÂ discernÂ a legit ICO from a scammy ICO, for instance. And if that is what point 3 is about, I think we then need to go back to listing the assumptions and examining if they are valid.

The disconnect in debate seems to stem from a failure to agree ontologically. InÂ particular, the definitions of the words "security", "currency" and "investment" are not standardizedÂ when people write aboutÂ cryptocurrency.At this point I personally would channel energy intoÂ debating how toÂ discernÂ a legit ICO from a scammy ICO, for instance. And if that is what point 3 is about, I think we then need to go back to listing the assumptions and examining if they are valid.

post_title: Discuss: Why the cryptocurrency discussion is going nowhere
content: Because speculative bubbles hurt the uninformed who get caught up in it.Â  Given a big enough speculative bubble it may hurt the overall economy.Â  For example, should the U.S. Government allow people to get sub-prime loans to invest into houses in hopes of real estate appreciation?Â  To some extent they can tolerate it.Â  But let it get out of hand and the housing bubble busts hurting a lot of people.Â  Enough people get hurt and it starts affecting the overall economy.

post_title: Opinion: Maybe programming really is rocket science
content:
I am sorry you feel this is a self-praise post. That means I didnâ€™t write clearly enough for you. My point is not that programmers are superior. We are not.

My point is that software projectsÂ can be large andÂ Â complex beasts that need a lot of careful planning andÂ expertise to complete in a good way.

If you put a bunch of â€œpeople who can do rocketsâ€ to make rockets, they will blow up. The same goes for software projects. If you put â€œpeople who can codeâ€ on complex software projects instead of trained programmers, then things go wrong. And if the managers who manage those projects donâ€™t understand that, then the projects will blow up.. just like rockets.

This has nothing to do with self-praise. This post is about having the right tool for the job, and sometimes theÂ tool is anÂ analogy.

Thanks for your comment!

These guys are really, really good.Â (Full disclosure:Â Megan isÂ speaking at a conference Iâ€™m putting together.) post_title: With upcoming IPO, Sea reveals net loss of $196m and revenue of $345m
content: I must admit, while this was long time coming, quite surprised that Sea took the IPO route in this environment and with these numbers. At the end of the day,Â Sea is a gaming company where almost all of its revenue comes from. And unless youâ€™re an EA or ATVI (or I guess Tencent), all gaming IPOs have been a dud in the last few years. Think of Zynga and King (which ultimately Tencent bought and took private). Even Rovio is planning to list on a significant discount on its last private valuation, even though itâ€™s profitable.With an ecommerce angle as well, Shopee is in a market that is very competitive with competition that has raised significantly larger cash arsenals. The closest ecommerce listing with similar angle, that I can think of that has had a successful public journey wasÂ MercadoLibre but it went public after it had already established itself as the clear leader in LATAM and in a much more forgiving public market with less valuation.Anyways, I hope Seaâ€™s IPO is a success, will be a huge shot in the arm for the SEA tech market, and a leg-up over their Indian counterparts, resulting in a bright future for the underfunded market.

And unless you're an EA or ATVI (or I guess Tencent), all gaming IPOs have been a dud in the last few years. Think of Zynga and King (which ultimately Tencent bought and took private). Even Rovio is planning to list on a significant discount on its last private valuation, even though it's profitable.With an ecommerce angle as well, Shopee is in a market that is very competitive with competition that has raised significantly larger cash arsenals. The closest ecommerce listing with similar angle, that I can think of that has had a successful public journey wasÂ MercadoLibre but it went public after it had already established itself as the clear leader in LATAM and in a much more forgiving public market with less valuation.Anyways, I hope Sea's IPO is a success, will be a huge shot in the arm for the SEA tech market, and a leg-up over their Indian counterparts, resulting in a bright future for the underfunded market.

post_title: With upcoming IPO, Sea reveals net loss of $196m and revenue of $345m
content: Online games publishingÂ is a hit and miss business, and online gamesÂ lifespan is getting shorter with more content available to the gamers.Â It is much harder for the regionalÂ publishingÂ company &Â they donâ€™tÂ own intellectual property of the games they publish in the region. Â There is a trend that the global game developers themselves are entering SE Asia region directly. Eg:Â Nexon has acquired local Thailand company and set-up Nexon Thailand. Â Blizzard previously worked with regionalÂ game publishers in SE Asia, but for the past few years they enter Southeast Asia directly by enabling their BattleNet digital platform with local payment channels. Â The popularity of digital distribution platforms like Facebook Game Room, Steam, Google Play and Apple App Store make it easier for game developers big and small to self publish their own games globally, instead of working with local publishers.

post_title: Instead of bashing RazerPay, we should focus on encouraging innovation
content: Top down approach may not be effective. Why PM Lee always mentioned the example of China. It is because China is by far the most successful country in using cashless payment, and why? Many researchers conducted the successful critical factors and one of the factors highlighted in their report is the bottom up approach: government only involved in few critical roles and ensuring the whole cashless payment process, i.e. clearing house etc. is secure and safe. The rest, leave it to the private enterprises, I.e. tencent, Alibaba etc. The user experience, both the consumers and the merchantsÂ  is another critical success factor in this process. They willingly to use the cashless payment for their own benefits, such as convenient, easy to use, safe and most importantly it is not force by the authority.
excerpt: Top down approach may not be effective. Why PM Lee always mentioned the example of China. It is because China is by far the most successful country in using cashless payment, and why? Many researchers conducted the successful critical factors and one of the factors highlighted in their report is the bottom up approach: government only involved in few critical roles and ensuring the whole cashless payment process, i.e. clearing house etc. is secure and safe. The rest, leave it to the private enterprises, I.e. tencent, Alibaba etc. The user experience, both the consumers and the merchantsÂ  is another critical success factor in this process. They willingly to use the cashless payment for their own benefits, such as convenient, easy to use, safe and most importantly it is not force by the authority.

post_title: Instead of bashing RazerPay, we should focus on encouraging innovation
content:
1.Â A lack of customer adoption

Ans: Integrating e-payment with other aspects of services, thus, providing larger value proposition (i.e. convenience & savings)Â to consumer leading to higher adoption rate.

2.Â Small merchantsâ€™ unwillingness to implement it

Ans: In general, improving ease of use & reduce competition will be the way to go but it is still a big obstacle to cross. It is associated with deeply root cultural behaviours from small merchants and their methods of conducting business since 20 years ago. Education will works but takes time to reap results. Simple solution will be for a top down approach by governing authority to insist all to adopt (e.g. forced transition from 2G to 3G phones).

3.Â Having different POS solutions

Ans: Universal POS terminal a.k.a. Mobile Phones ğŸ˜‰

post_title: Opinion: Hereâ€™s a warning for businesses as people demand more honesty on social media
content:
Ryan, this was a brilliant read.Â Thanks for sharing. I would like to share my opinion.

Social Media platforms (except for Snapchat) are essentially megaphones for attentionÂ seekers;Â check-ins, pathetically photoshopped selfies, the constant urge to get more likes/views/comments, its a malignant disease.

Isnâ€™t it ridiculous to view a post mourning a terrorist attack that killed many followed by a check-inn at a 7 star restaurant for a 19 course meal with a disgusting selfie.

Lets get real, most of theÂ Social Media platforms areÂ unreal, fake, does not reflect anything other than self-obsession.

I wish there could be a platform that encourages you to be the real you, a completeÂ stripped down version, no pretensions, no fallacies, no facades, just the unfiltered you.

post_title: Discuss: Will bike-sharing survive?
content:
Ugh. Itâ€™s an eyesore to see those bicycles strewn willy nilly all over the place here in Singapore. The bicycles themselves arenâ€™t very good in quality as theyâ€™re meant to be as cheap as possible, and there was no pleasure to be had in riding them.

Worse still, the treatment of those bicycles by its users is a very apt reflection on who we are as a society: there is no conscientiousness at all in the way they are just left behind at random, and because users donâ€™t own the bikes there is no care given to their condition and maintenance.

Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with using the fixed bike station model, because itâ€™s all about the execution of it. The so-called Boris Bikes of London was a huge success since its implementation by former mayor Boris Johnson, but then again I remain eternally skeptical of â€œbike sharingâ€Â as a service. Itâ€™s there to gather data of consumer travel and daily commute habits, and that data is to be sold to someone else â€“ the bikes are just a vehicle for harvesting that data.
excerpt: Ugh. It's an eyesore to see those bicycles strewn willy nilly all over the place here in Singapore. The bicycles themselves aren't very good in quality as they're meant to be as cheap as possible, and there was no pleasure to be had in riding them.Worse still, the treatment of those bicycles by its users is a very apt reflection on who we are as a society: there is no conscientiousness at all in the way they are just left behind at random, and because users don't own the bikes there is no care given to their condition and maintenance.There's nothing wrong with using the fixed bike station model, because it's all about the execution of it. The so-called Boris Bikes of London was a huge success since its implementation by former mayor Boris Johnson, but then again I remain eternally skeptical of "bike sharing"Â as a service. It's there to gather data of consumer travel and daily commute habits, and that data is to be sold to someone else - the bikes are just a vehicle for harvesting that data.

post_title: Video: Cashier-less stores are catching on in China
content:
I personally felt disappointed with Bingoboxâ€™s experience. There seemed to be excessive QR code scanning during the whole process â€“ and overall I thought that a vending machine would have been muchÂ simpler, faster, and more convenient (though you collect less data with a vending machine I suppose).

For instance, multiple people entering the store simultaneously or consecutively seemed to be a problem. You have to scan the QR code in order to unlock the door â€“ and Bingobox reminds you to be wary of people trailing in behind you. Â To leave the store, you also had to scan a QR code. Plus payment, thatâ€™s 3 times. In the grand scheme of things, itâ€™s not a big deal but when you have to take out your phone 3 times in order to buy a bag of chips and toothpaste,Â a vending machine sounds a lot simpler.
excerpt: I personally felt disappointed with Bingobox's experience. There seemed to be excessive QR code scanning during the whole process - and overall I thought that a vending machine would have been muchÂ simpler, faster, and more convenient (though you collect less data with a vending machine I suppose).For instance, multiple people entering the store simultaneously or consecutively seemed to be a problem. You have to scan the QR code in order to unlock the door - and Bingobox reminds you to be wary of people trailing in behind you. Â To leave the store, you also had to scan a QR code. Plus payment, that's 3 times. In the grand scheme of things, it's not a big deal but when you have to take out your phone 3 times in order to buy a bag of chips and toothpaste,Â a vending machine sounds a lot simpler.

post_title: Discuss: People are irrational, so donâ€™t put too much time on testing product-market fit
content: My working style has always been OptionÂ F, which led me to obtaining over USD 2 million in IAP in my previous company. In my current company, the seniorÂ management loves Option C, doing things solely based on historical data and a fixed formula. They are unwilling to change even if there hasnâ€™t been any financiallyÂ successful products over the past 2 years.I agree with the notion that consumers these days are irrational and their behavior changes on a regular basis. The best option to monitor the market and adjust strategies is to do regular follow-ups and not based everything on forecasts and a fixed mathematical formula from years ago.

post_title: Razerâ€™s Tan responds after Nets CEO questions epayments proposal
content:
Yes, Nets has been around a long time, & is widely used for payments with Debit cards. Â Â But where mobileÂ cashlessÂ payments in Sg is concerned â€“ it is stillÂ aÂ complete mess with multiple platforms in 2017.Â 

Why didnâ€™t Jeffrey Goh put his new cashless system in years earlier if it was the market leader? Â 

Why did PMÂ Lee askÂ Razerâ€™s Tan Minliang to initiate one instead of Netsâ€™ Jeffrey GohÂ ? Â Â 

Why did JeffreyÂ announce his system one week after Razerâ€™s ? Â All that 2nd announcement didÂ was to detract focus onÂ Tanâ€™s reply to the PM of aÂ viable solution to the un-unified mobile cashless payment problem. Â 

If a third party announces another cashless payment system this week, weâ€™ll never see the end of a viable solution. Â Just anotherÂ mess of wires under the table.
excerpt: Yes, Nets has been around a long time, & is widely used for payments with Debit cards. Â Â But where mobileÂ cashlessÂ payments in Sg is concerned - it is stillÂ aÂ complete mess with multiple platforms in 2017.Â Why didn't Jeffrey Goh put his new cashless system in years earlier if it was the market leader? Â Why did PMÂ Lee askÂ Razer's Tan Minliang to initiate one instead of Nets' Jeffrey GohÂ ? Â Â Why did JeffreyÂ announce his system one week after Razer's ? Â All that 2nd announcement didÂ was to detract focus onÂ Tan's reply to the PM of aÂ viable solution to the un-unified mobile cashless payment problem. Â If a third party announces another cashless payment system this week, we'll never see the end of a viable solution. Â Just anotherÂ mess of wires under the table.

content: Good and informative. Something I took from this is, I think as a founder one must give his all in terms of time, effort and money so as to really succeed. Having started a startup out of the fad I failed because I had a place to fall back to (My parents). In our South Asian culture one reason startups rarely make it out must be that we have someone out there holding our back and we always have out foot on 2 boats. Thanks for the article. Would love to get some insight on the organic growth and the details to how you learned hard and achieved it.Â

post_title: Opinion: Alibabaâ€™s first mall shows that O2O is a real business model
content: Interesting and to me this makes a lot of sense.From personal experience:Â we have been following this business model inÂ Indonesia with ROOMOOMO since 2016Â â€“ being a primary online luxury fashion retailer, we find that through offline presence (in our case through pop-up events in different cities), we can not only make the items more accessible, but also convert offline customers to online customers later on. Important here is of course to have technology that brings these two worlds together well (e.g. having customers register an account, or having the offline sale process through the online platform etc.)Excited to see if other small players will now follow suit more, and how it plays out at large for Alibaba.
excerpt: Interesting and to me this makes a lot of sense.From personal experience:Â we have been following this business model inÂ Indonesia with ROOMOOMO since 2016Â - being a primary online luxury fashion retailer, we find that through offline presence (in our case through pop-up events in different cities), we can not only make the items more accessible, but also convert offline customers to online customers later on. Important here is of course to have technology that brings these two worlds together well (e.g. having customers register an account, or having the offline sale process through the online platform etc.)Excited to see if other small players will now follow suit more, and how it plays out at large for Alibaba.

post_title: Accelerators scramble for new revenue streams as equity model fails
content:
No surprises here. Acceleration programs tend to attract the worst of startups. If you, as a founder, actually had the business/technical ability to make a â€œhockystickâ€/â€unicornâ€ business, why the heck would you join an accelerator and â€œlearn to be a founderâ€? Itâ€™s just retarded.Â 

Accelerators are government/corporate money sinks. They are magnets for dumb money looking for a home. As long as the accelerator can point to their â€œworld classâ€ team of â€œprofessional startup go-gettersâ€, government and corporate busybodies just canâ€™t wait to dump money in to satisfy the quota handed down from HQ on $$ that needs to be â€œinvestedâ€ in â€œinnovationâ€.

Such BS.

If you, as a founder, actually had the business/technical ability to make a "hockystick"/"unicorn" business, why the heck would you join an accelerator and "learn to be a founder"? As long as the accelerator can point to their "world class" team of "professional startup go-getters", government and corporate busybodies just can't wait to dump money in to satisfy the quota handed down from HQ on $$ that needs to be "invested" in "innovation".Such BS.

This will certainly come across asÂ self-serving, as Iâ€™m affiliated with UCÂ Berkeley SkyDeck, a globalÂ academic accelerator located on campus at UCÂ Berkeleyâ€¦Â But I would certainly caution against painting accelerators with too broad of a brush.Â Â I doÂ question the roles some accelerators claim to play in the ecosystemâ€¦Â asÂ the value ofÂ â€œadviceâ€ itself is extremely difficult to price, and many accelerators are run more by marketers than experienced entrepreneurs. Â But in the course of my investingÂ career, Iâ€™ve seen many entrepreneurs (including future â€˜unicornsâ€™) benefit significantly from a well-designed incubator that helps openÂ the right doors, to the right people, at the right time.

And as to the point of the articleâ€¦Â Â one of the advantages of being an official accelerator thatâ€™s part of the institution, is that our operating costs are supported byÂ UCÂ Berkeley!

post_title: Discuss: Do we actually know what a pivot means?
content:
Agree thatÂ people generallyÂ (myselfÂ included)Â define â€œpivotâ€Â in narrower terms than Steve does.Â IÂ think people associate pivots specifically with product pivots just because they tend to have a greater ripple effectÂ (i.e. it could substantively change so much of the other parts).Â Other pivots can be more contained, and you can argue that theyâ€™re not unique to startups.

Semantics aside, IÂ think whatâ€™s crucial to a startupâ€™s success isÂ the ability to fix things/solve problems/react to changes rapidly and flexibly, whether or not it results in a pivot.
excerpt: Agree thatÂ people generallyÂ (myselfÂ included)Â define "pivot"Â in narrower terms than Steve does.Â IÂ think people associate pivots specifically with product pivots just because they tend to have a greater ripple effectÂ (i.e. it could substantively change so much of the other parts).Â Other pivots can be more contained, and you can argue that they're not unique to startups.Semantics aside, IÂ think what's crucial to a startup's success isÂ the ability to fix things/solve problems/react to changes rapidly and flexibly, whether or not it results in a pivot.

post_title: Discuss: Do we actually know what a pivot means?
content: Definitely agree that a pivot isnâ€™t just about changing the product but also about the business model. After all, some business models are also drastically different.Â The key word here, of course, is that the change should be substantive, regardless of where that change is occurring.

post_title: Opinion: Appleâ€™s iPhone X storage options are a cruel joke
content:
Iâ€™m aware that thereâ€™s a difference in cost, and originally I had a line in the article about that. I took it out, though, because I donâ€™t think it matters, for a few reasons:

First, what Iâ€™m talking about there is the userâ€™s needs, not the cost to Apple. IfÂ Apple started iPod Classic storage options at 80 GBÂ and then went up from there, they must have thought that might not be enough storage for some users, right? Some iPod users would only need 80 GB, but some would need more. OK.Â But ten years later, they offerÂ less storage on a device that does a lot more and that often deals with way bigger files. So, forgetting about the comparative cost, can you make an argument as to why an iPhone X user in 2017 would need less storage space than an iPod classic user in 2007?

Second, the cost comparison isnâ€™t as black-and-white as youâ€™re suggesting anyway. HDDs haveÂ always been cheaper than solid-state storage, yes. But were HDDs in 2007 cheaper than SSDs in late 2017? Iâ€™m not as sure. Obviously neither of us have historical data on what Appleâ€™s suppliers were charging. But some chartsÂ I found like this one suggest HDD storage may have been as much as 10x more expensive per GBÂ in 2007 than it is now for industrial-scale buyers. And of course, over the past ten years, the price of SSDs has also fallen dramatically.Â 

Iâ€™m guessing even with all of that, 80GB of HDD in 2007 might have cost Apple slightly less than 80 GB of SSD would today. But even that doesnâ€™t really matter, becauseâ€¦.

Third, the iPhone XÂ costs 4x what an 80 GB iPhone Classic cost. Apple, at least historically, tends to sell its hardware with massive profit margins. Thanks to those margins, Apple also has hundreds of billions of dollars in cash. Given all of that, do we really think that the decision to start the iPhone X at 64 GBÂ was driven by Appleâ€™s inability to make a higher-storage option financially viable? I donâ€™t find that very likely.

IfÂ Apple started iPod Classic storage options at 80 GBÂ and then went up from there, they must have thought that might not be enough storage for some users, right? Some iPod users would only need 80 GB, but some would need more. OK.Â But ten years later, they offerÂ less storage on a device that does a lot more and that often deals with way bigger files. Second, the cost comparison isnâ€™t as black-and-white as youâ€™re suggesting anyway. HDDs haveÂ always been cheaper than solid-state storage, yes. But some chartsÂ I found like this one suggest HDD storage may have been as much as 10x more expensive per GBÂ in 2007 than it is now for industrial-scale buyers. And of course, over the past ten years, the price of SSDs has also fallen dramatically.Â 

Iâ€™m guessing even with all of that, 80GB of HDD in 2007 might have cost Apple slightly less than 80 GB of SSD would today. But even that doesnâ€™t really matter, becauseâ€¦.

post_title: Nets makes its pitch to upgrade Singaporeâ€™s epayments landscape
content: nowadays, we can make bills payment from anywhere using our mobile phone. why cant transactions be done between a seller and buyer by just using their mobile phones e.g. like wechat pay, alipay, stripe, etc.? the new PayNow system is the right way to go. Traditional big players are known to be too slow in implementing change as they have invested a lot in the traditional system and prefer to improve or reuse them than dumping them. They should do away with the traditional nets terminal and receipt printing.Â Â While they have been comfortable with their â€˜monopolyâ€™ in epayment for many years, you only hear them in the news when the PM woke them up. New players with fresh ideas and solutions should come in to distrupt this area.Â Nowadays, the one with the lowest cost and most convenient wins the game regardless of how big you are.Â

Equal diversity is an ideal, and ideal is not necessarily the reality. It is like trying to sell a product that you think is perfect to a market that donâ€™t want it. It just doesnâ€™t work. And why push moreÂ women into tech? What merit is there? Just to satisfy your ideal?

content:
Thanks for touching on the frustrating problem of gender diversity, because the answer is to change an entire culture, and thereâ€™s no quick fix for that.

post_title: Report: China shutting down cryptocurrency exchanges
content:
I think you â€” and many others â€” are misinterpreting the report. Bitcoin and Ether are specifically NOTÂ affected.Â 

You write:Â â€œTo be clear, the report doesÂ notÂ suggest that individual ownership or exchange of digital currencies will be banned. However, with RMB-to-cryptocurrency exchanges all closed, it would be difficult for most Chinese users to acquire or exchange digital currencies like Bitcoin or Ether.Â â€œ

The report and announcements specifically say blockchain, bitcoin and ether are not affected. They are simply banning the use of exchanges that are converting fiat into the newly launched ICOÂ tokens, of which there are over 65 native to China alone.Â 

You could read this really good editorial to get a better sense of what is actually going on. I think your reporting slightly misunderstands the issue. Â Read this:Â https://bitcoinmagazine.com/arâ€¦Â

post_title: Report: China shutting down cryptocurrency exchanges
content:
I think you have misunderstood what this article is about. You (and the op-ed you linked) areÂ talking about the ICOÂ ban, which was officially announced a few days ago.Â This isnâ€™t about that. This article is about a more recentÂ report in Caixin (there have been no official announcements) that China is shutting all domestic cryptocurrency exchanges.

Hereâ€™s the first sentence of the Caixin story: â€œä»¥æ¯”ç‰¹å¸ã€ä»¥å¤ªåŠä¸ºä»£è¡¨çš„æ‰€æœ‰è™šæ‹Ÿè´§å¸ä¸äººæ°‘å¸ä¹‹é—´çš„å¢ƒå†…äº¤æ˜“æ‰€å°†å…¨éƒ¨é™æœŸå…³é—­;Â ä½†ç›‘ç®¡å¹¶éé’ˆå¯¹è™šæ‹Ÿè´§å¸æœ¬èº«ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰ç¦æ­¢è™šæ‹Ÿè´§å¸ä¸€å¯¹ä¸€çš„åœºå¤–äº¤æ˜“ã€‚â€Hereâ€™s a rough translation of that: â€œAll domestic exchanges that exchange RMB for cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ether will be closed, but authorities arenâ€™t targeting cryptocurrencies themselves and havenâ€™t banned person-to-person exchange.â€

IF this report is true (and it might not be), it would absolutely affect BTC and ETH, at least in the sense that all the major Chinese exchanges like Huobi, OKCoin, BTCChina, etc. would be shut down, making buying and selling these currencies much harder in China. But weâ€™ll have to see. The ICOÂ ban youâ€™re talking about is definite and has been announced officially, but this has NOTÂ been officially announced yet so we really donâ€™t know how it will play out.

post_title: Opinion: Why Australia is the best place for Asian startups right now
content: Lack of resources (human & $), high costs and taxes, small population of only 24m people in AU, too much regulations and laws that are preventing significant innovation and creativity. Startups in AU are just copycats of what have been created somewhere else or just a software extension of what was already created previously by someone else. Technically just â€œanother software companyâ€ like those in the 90s.Â VCs in AU are less willing to take risks compared to those in Asia, US and Europe. They somehow practice â€œlow risk = high returnâ€, odd enough. Canâ€™t compare AU VCs with Sequoia and SoftBank, these two are more aggressive and willing to take risks.Very small government grants and initiatives to support startups compared to SG Smart Nation program fundings. A $1bn tax exemption â€œgrantsâ€ initiated by Malcolm Turnbull in Sept 2015 was simply a joke, it wasnâ€™t cash, it was tax exemption.Â Very low tech absorption by the society compared to Asia and the rest of the world.

A $1bn tax exemption â€œgrantsâ€ initiated by Malcolm Turnbull in Sept 2015 was simply a joke, it wasnâ€™t cash, it was tax exemption.Â Very low tech absorption by the society compared to Asia and the rest of the world.

post_title: After attending and teaching at coding bootcamps, hereâ€™s why I say theyâ€™re worth it
content:
Eh, I donâ€™t know. Thereâ€™s a reason two major bootcampsÂ closed. They donâ€™t produce engineers, 4-year computer science programs produce engineers.Â 3 months bootcamps at best produce relatively clueless light all developers who now know how to search for the rightÂ information. Companies have to be willing to take a chance on these people, and bootcamps are now closing because that gap in the market is closing. Companies now need solid engineers.Â Sure there are exceptions, and some people REALLY take to it. But generally, thatâ€™s whatâ€™s up.

Also, the financial analysis of taking or not taking a boot camp is inherently flawed because it assumes that youâ€™ll just go and get a job afterwards. And that youâ€™ll stay at it. And that youâ€™re even good enough to do it, and the company was willing to take a chance on you. Anyway, you get the gyst!

They don't produce engineers, 4-year computer science programs produce engineers.Â 3 months bootcamps at best produce relatively clueless light all developers who now know how to search for the rightÂ information. post_title: After attending and teaching at coding bootcamps, hereâ€™s why I say theyâ€™re worth it
content:
Everything you wrote here is based on your preconceived notion that in general, bootcamp grads make poor engineers. Itâ€™s an attitude that many seasoned developers unfortunately share. Please let me try to change your view.

CLOSINGÂ BOOTCAMPS

Thereâ€™s a reason two major bootcampsÂ closed.

The reason Dev Bootcamp and The Iron Yard closed is because of increased competition. They were some of the first coding bootcamps to emerge. As bootcamps get more popular and more openÂ up, of course some of them are going to close down.

Dev Bootcamp in particular closed largelyÂ because it was not very good. Itâ€™s fairlyÂ well known that their graduates, in general, were not adequate developers when they came out. Itâ€™s a failing of thatÂ bootcamp, not bootcamps in general.

Itâ€™s a relatively new industry. Thereâ€™s going to be some chaos. If you see aÂ rideshare service closing down, would you say that ridesharing is doomed and impractical?

BOOTCAMPSÂ VSÂ DEGREES

They donâ€™t produce engineers, 4-year computer science programs produce engineers.Â 3 months bootcamps at best produce relatively clueless light all developers who now know how to search for the rightÂ information.

Bootcamps produce engineers. Computer science programsÂ produce engineers. The difference is that computer science programs provide a lot moreÂ knowledge, the large majority of which is not necessary orÂ irrelevant for software engineering.

Iâ€™m going to paraphrase the author of Cracking the Coding Interview,Â Gayle Laakmann McDowell, from this post. I encourage you to read it.Â This is a person who has interviewed hundreds of software candidates for companies all over the country, including Google.

Essentially, her point is that the computer science major can be boiled down to ~14Â classes, once the general studies courses that universities require are removed. Of those, ~10Â are electives, math, and low-level architecture, which are not necessary. This leaves 4 classes, which is completely feasible for 3 months of directed study. If you donâ€™t believe that 4 classes is all thatâ€™s necessary, take a look at the article I linked above.

Of course, bootcamp students will miss some stuff, but â€œThatâ€™s fair, since their goal is to create programmers, not academics. Theyâ€™ll replace that â€œmissingâ€ stuff with a lot of more practical knowledge.â€

Yes, people with CS degrees have much more experience than bootcamp grads. After all, itâ€™s 3 months vs. 4 years. That 3 months, however, is packed with the most relevant industry knowledge possible. Itâ€™s also ridiculously cheaper than a 4-year degree.

Companies have to be willing to take a chance on these people, and bootcamps are now closing because that gap in the market is closing. Companies now need solid engineers.

Itâ€™s true that these grads will be very junior. However, that isnâ€™t a fault of bootcamps. These people need time to get better and to hone their skills. However, I can speak with experience that theyÂ come out with skills necessary to do well as developers if they start working right away.

MYÂ EXPERIENCE

I attended a bootcamp right after finishing my undergraduate degree. IÂ got a higher-paying job in less time than most of my friends. IÂ was surprised, but it made sense. IÂ had spent 3 months working 60 hours/week, learning material that was built to jump-start my career into modern software engineering. It worked.

Many of the students in the bootcamp Iâ€™m currently teaching will get a job within a few months of graduating. Theyâ€™re quite good. They can build full applications on their own at this point.

FINANCIALÂ ANALYSIS

Also, the financial analysis of taking or not taking a boot camp is inherently flawed because it assumes that youâ€™ll just go and get a job afterwards. And that youâ€™ll stay at it. And that youâ€™re even good enough to do it, and the company was willing to take a chance on you.

My article was aimed at people who want to get a job in software engineering. I assume that theyâ€™ll apply for jobs as soon as they can and stay at it. If they donâ€™t, then of course, a bootcamp is a $10,000 sinkhole. Same goes for a college degree, but with a much bigger number.

Yes, a company has to take a chance on you. Itâ€™s a slightly bigger chance than it is for a university graduate.Â Yes, you have to be good and applying for jobs has to become yourÂ full-time job.

If someone has trouble getting a job out of a bootcamp, they would have had trouble getting a job after self-study as well. It evens out.

As I mention in the article, it wonâ€™t work out for some.Â For the large majority of dedicated, intelligent bootcamp students, it will.

They were some of the first coding bootcamps to emerge. As bootcamps get more popular and more openÂ up, of course some of them are going to close down.Dev Bootcamp in particular closed largelyÂ because it was not very good. post_title: Chinese ecommerce giant shows off its first ever â€˜robot warehouseâ€™
content:
Anyone saying robotic automation, and other automation driven by AIÂ and ML, will not take a majority of peopleâ€™s jobs, are absolutely clueless.Â The different between the industrial revolution, and tech now, is a matter of exponential growth in device intelligence and harnessing of power. Trying to say â€œpeople didnâ€™t lose their jobs due to the industrial revolution, so why now?â€ is just a waste of time.

Simple fact of the matter is, as the intelligence of devices and control systems gets closer to human ability, exponentially more humans are going to be dropped out of the category of â€œproductive workersâ€, where â€œproductive workersâ€ are anyone who can actually add net value to a business.

Things are only accelerating. The next 40 years is going to be full of world-wide mass unemployment (starting in low-skill jobs and developing countries), leading to societal change on a scale similar or greater then the move from monarchies to alternative forms of government.

Letâ€™s pray we manage societal change before the owners of capital (aka the owners of the AI and robotics systems) are able to close the loop and lock in their control of the system.

Trying to say "people didn't lose their jobs due to the industrial revolution, so why now?" is just a waste of time.Simple fact of the matter is, as the intelligence of devices and control systems gets closer to human ability, exponentially more humans are going to be dropped out of the category of "productive workers", where "productive workers" are anyone who can actually add net value to a business.Things are only accelerating. The next 40 years is going to be full of world-wide mass unemployment (starting in low-skill jobs and developing countries), leading to societal change on a scale similar or greater then the move from monarchies to alternative forms of government.Let's pray we manage societal change before the owners of capital (aka the owners of the AI and robotics systems) are able to close the loop and lock in their control of the system.

post_title: What we found analyzing Indonesian ride-hailing companiesâ€™ social media performance
content:
Hey Harry, thanks for the comment. Thatâ€™s the broad idea yes! However there is one more angle to take which is shown in the graph for Interactivity Index (the last one). When taking the data from our tool at Sotrender, the total sum of this Interactivity Index is about 30% higher for Go-Jek than Grab during the given time period (Mid Jan- theÂ end of July).Â 

Thereâ€™s also the level of interaction on Twitter which can be evaluated since thatâ€™s where a lot of interactions take place between the brands and their customers (Grab has a high ratio of actions/day to the number of followers on Twitter for example in comparison to Go-Jek) so this can be dissected quite further! (alas, time and article length are constraints :D)

What do you think about these factors?Â 

Hisham

post_title: Discuss: Singapore is making a universal payment system. But there are better options
content:
Actually it is really not about discovering anÂ ultimate killer robust payment system solution. It is the cost of implementing andÂ using the e-payment for the vendors/seller. No matter how good is your e-payment solution, as long as it is expensive to use, it will never takeÂ off.

Assume cost is not a factor, we already have the solution. Just use EZLINK card for everything. All the transport system already implemented, some of the retailer already implemented. Just expand on it. Continue to promote it. Mandate use everywhere. (remember, if cost is not a factor)

Let user easily link their credit cards, giro, debit card to their EZLINK and start using it. It is fast and reasonably secure. Let EZLINK card to become a virtual debit card to purchase items online.Â 

You see we already have the e-payment solution and actually quite established. Why are they not popular? It is the COST of implementation and using it that prevents retailer, hawker from using it.

Imagine, cost of implementing EZLINK system and transaction costÂ is negligible, tap and buy food at hawker is a breeze. tap to buy items at 7-11 is fast, tap to buy grocery at ntuc, tap to take cab, take bus, tap to pay bill at AXS, tap to pay bill at town council. And if mobile phone is also a EZLINK terminal, you can tap at your friend phone to pay him money.

With linked EZLINK card, everything withdraw from your bank account or credit card.Â 

Sounds good? why need another system.

and of course another reason is selfish commercial entities. â€œwhy should i implement the already very established EZLINK system, i want people to use my paylah, i want people to use my singtel dash, i want people to use my ntuc branded credit card, i want people to use my grabpay, i want people to use my razor-payment-system-wannabeâ€

Need to clarify, i am not from EZLINK or affiliated with EZLINK. It is my opinion that EZLINK has the established network, why not think of how to expand on it.Â 

Or think of revolution ways to reduce theÂ cost of implementing and using e-payment solution. Eg. bitcoin is a very innovative concept of transferring fund cross border without the extortionist bankÂ transaction cost.
excerpt:
Actually it is really not about discovering anÂ ultimate killer robust payment system solution. It is the cost of implementing andÂ using the e-payment for the vendors/seller. No matter how good is your e-payment solution, as long as it is expensive to use, it will never takeÂ off.
Assume cost is not a factor, we already have the solution. Just use EZLINK card for everything. All the transport system already implemented, some of the retailer already implemented. Just expand on it. Continue to promote it. Mandate use everywhere. (remember, if cost is not a factor)
Let user easily link their credit cards, giro, debit card to their EZLINK and start using it. It is fast and reasonably secure. Let EZLINK card to become a virtual debit card to purchase items online.Â 
You see we already have the e-payment solution and actually quite established. Why are they not popular? It is the COST of implementation and using it that prevents retailer, hawker from using it.
Imagine, cost of implementing EZLINK system and transaction costÂ is negligible, tap and buy food at hawker is a breeze. tap to buy items at 7-11 is fast, tap to buy grocery at ntuc, tap to take cab, take bus, tap to pay bill at AXS, tap to pay bill at town council. And if mobile phone is also a EZLINK terminal, you can tap at your friend phone to pay him money.
With linked EZLINK card, everything withdraw from your bank account or credit card.Â 
Sounds good? why need another system.
and of course another reason is selfish commercial entities. â€œwhy should i implement the already very established EZLINK system, i want people to use my paylah, i want people to use my singtel dash, i want people to use my ntuc branded credit card, i want people to use my grabpay, i want people to use my razor-payment-system-wannabeâ€
Need to clarify, i am not from EZLINK or affiliated with EZLINK. It is my opinion that EZLINK has the established network, why not think of how to expand on it.Â 
Or think of revolution ways to reduce theÂ cost of implementing and using e-payment solution. Eg. bitcoin is a very innovative concept of transferring fund cross border without the extortionist bankÂ transaction cost.

post_title: Discuss: Singapore is making a universal payment system. But there are better options
content:
Adding another payment system is not the solution to the problem that there are already too many payment systems!

Banks (and other providers of payment solutions) should work together to come to a standard. The IDEAL system mentioned in Robinâ€™s post sounds interesting. The point is, there should be no need for a merchant to have three or more credit card machines for different cards. The chip or NFC interfaces are certainly not the reason for that.Â 

The public transport system in London is a great example of how it should be. You tap in and out of the subway or public bussesÂ with a card, just like you do with an EZ-Link card in Singapore. But it is not limited to the Oyster cards, the London equivalent to the EZ-Link card. You can use any contactless payment cardsÂ issued by banks and credit card providers. Also Apple Pay works flawlessly and I believeÂ Android payment options are supported as well. So instead of searching for a fare card I simply touch the Â  gate to the subway or the terminal in the bus with my Apple Watch and the fare gets billed to my Amex card. This is very handy if you are carrying a few shopping bags! Of course QR code based payment systems have the advantage that you donâ€™t need a special terminal for payment, but can you imagine the queues to the MRT in the morning if everyone had to capture QR codes at the gate with their smart phone and wait for the gate to receive the paymentÂ to enter and exit the MRT stations?Â How much longer will a bus ride take if users have to snap QR codes with their phones when they board and alight?Â  Â 

If subway gates and busses can accept all kinds of contactless payment cards and payments via NFCÂ from phones and smart watches, there can be a simple terminal that merchants can use to accept all these forms of payment as well. That is what we need, not yet another payment system. Â Â Of course that requires collaboration between the banks/payment systems, which may have to be encouraged/enforced by the government.

The IDEAL system mentioned in Robin's post sounds interesting. The point is, there should be no need for a merchant to have three or more credit card machines for different cards. The chip or NFC interfaces are certainly not the reason for that.Â The public transport system in London is a great example of how it should be. You tap in and out of the subway or public bussesÂ with a card, just like you do with an EZ-Link card in Singapore. But it is not limited to the Oyster cards, the London equivalent to the EZ-Link card. You can use any contactless payment cardsÂ issued by banks and credit card providers. Also Apple Pay works flawlessly and I believeÂ Android payment options are supported as well. So instead of searching for a fare card I simply touch the Â  gate to the subway or the terminal in the bus with my Apple Watch and the fare gets billed to my Amex card. This is very handy if you are carrying a few shopping bags! Of course QR code based payment systems have the advantage that you don't need a special terminal for payment, but can you imagine the queues to the MRT in the morning if everyone had to capture QR codes at the gate with their smart phone and wait for the gate to receive the paymentÂ to enter and exit the MRT stations?Â How much longer will a bus ride take if users have to snap QR codes with their phones when they board and alight?Â  Â If subway gates and busses can accept all kinds of contactless payment cards and payments via NFCÂ from phones and smart watches, there can be a simple terminal that merchants can use to accept all these forms of payment as well. That is what we need, not yet another payment system. Â Â Of course that requires collaboration between the banks/payment systems, which may have to be encouraged/enforced by the government.

post_title: Discuss: Singapore is making a universal payment system. But there are better options
content: I am Dutch and in The Netherlands we have IDEAL.Â (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/â€¦). I think that is a very smartÂ banking model that Singapore should explore. It will require centralization of banking infrastructure, but since the SGÂ government now seems open toÂ that anyway I would go for a similar approach. Whatever e-payment system you then put on top is not that relevant I think. E-payment isÂ justÂ a feature.Â The added value of banks is not in their logistics or e-payment solutions, it is in their service. In Singapore most banks seem to have forgotten about that.Â We now have I donâ€™t know how many options, because it is build from the bankÂ (or taxiâ€™s, or websites, orâ€¦.)Â perspective, not the user/service perspective. With an IDEALÂ kind of setupÂ we can loose the 5 atmâ€™s per MRTÂ station, GIROÂ and FAST pricing to wire money from bank to bank, etc.. The consumer can thenÂ pay for what is distinguishable between banks, not for flavours of the same. And the government gets back in control of the money supply which IÂ think is the underlying reason they are looking into this in the first place.

With an IDEALÂ kind of setupÂ we can loose the 5 atm's per MRTÂ station, GIROÂ and FAST pricing to wire money from bank to bank, etc.. The consumer can thenÂ pay for what is distinguishable between banks, not for flavours of the same. And the government gets back in control of the money supply which IÂ think is the underlying reason they are looking into this in the first place.

post_title: Discuss: Singapore is making a universal payment system. But there are better options
content:
1. Why does Singapore need a universal epayments system? Why does it have to be mandated?

2. What are the security measures in place? Furthermore, to be paternalistic, how will we address the overspending issue that comes with frictionless epayments?

3. Yes, the solution is doable. But similarly, given the governmentâ€™s control over the economy, it can mandate that Singapore uses cowrie shells and use the resulting adoption rates as proof of success. But does it improve the net welfare of the society?

post_title: Discuss: Singapore is making a universal payment system. But there are better options
content: QR codes can be spoofed and can be made device independent. In order to authenticate transactions completely, using digital identity(device based) they have to be frequency based with matching keys on both devices. Frequency based emissions ensure physical proximity and matching keys will only allow those specific phones to transact. Lastly, we donâ€™t need a universal system,Â we just need a domestic system good enough for our own culture and people to adapt, and it can always be interledger based with global systems. For Singaporeans, by Singaporeans first lah! ğŸ™‚
excerpt: QR codes can be spoofed and can be made device independent. In order to authenticate transactions completely, using digital identity(device based) they have to be frequency based with matching keys on both devices. Frequency based emissions ensure physical proximity and matching keys will only allow those specific phones to transact. Lastly, we don't need a universal system,Â we just need a domestic system good enough for our own culture and people to adapt, and it can always be interledger based with global systems. For Singaporeans, by Singaporeans first lah! :)

It would indeed be better to â€˜encourageâ€™ localÂ retailers to supportÂ existing systems. Some food courts for instance have gone down the mobile payment track already, where-as others are still cash only (and I talk about big chains here).

post_title: In China, KFC tests out â€˜smile to payâ€™
content:
Itâ€™s an interesting idea but I withhold judgementÂ due to the challenges in 1) facial recognition accuracy; 2) external environment (lighting/crowds/dirty cams etc); 3) false positives. The last of which is critical â€“ how does one acknowledge whether the recognition is right or wrong and not take advantage when itâ€™s wrong?

I hope KFC would share their test results and experiences so the industry can learn from them.

post_title: Why we rather have simple dinners than scale too fast with investor money
content:
Regarding â€œUnicorn Huntâ€Â â€“ agree with you. Startups trying to look good in front of investors andÂ â€œscale upâ€Â to meet their hockey-stick-like growth charts are *everywhere*.

Wish I saw more startups moving slowly like what Basecamp has done with their success.Â 

Startups should have massive demand *already locked in* before even considering to hire someone. Work-load should be overflowing to the point of team members physically having problems keeping up before someone new is brought in.

For most startupâ€™s expenses, *especially* in the tech sphere, salaries make up nearly all of the actual expenses. I just cannot understand why there are so many idiotic founders who think that just because they got a influx of cash, can go out and double/triple/etc.. the size of their team IN EXPECTATION of massive growth. Dumb.

Keep up the good work with Picapage. Keep that team small and lean, build out revenue, and build a foundation that you guys can grow the next 100+ years.

Thanks for the article.

post_title: Discuss: I used Grab and Uber in Myanmar. Hereâ€™s what I think they can improve on
content:
I think you should have done a little more research, or asked some of us who live in Yangon to clarify some things. First off, GRABÂ also allows you to use your credit card if itâ€™s linked.

Second, drivers in other markets donâ€™t have great English either, which is why Â I love using ride hailing apps in foreign places â€“ you donâ€™t have to speak to the drivers. I will note that the drivers here donâ€™t really know how to read maps yet so IÂ often get frustrated with that but thatâ€™s getting better.

Given that UBERÂ and GRABÂ have both entered the market for only a few months, they are â€œchuckingâ€ promotions to gain market share but also to educate the market. This is to be expected as they launch. Additionally, I would ask if you have brand loyalty to GRABÂ or UBERÂ in other markets?Â They are pretty much commodities offering pretty much the exact same thing, right?

That said, in informal polls with locals and drivers, Iâ€™m starting to hear that GRABÂ is winningâ€¦both for their ongoing promotions which pretty much gives you free rides everywhere during the day. Also, they are cheaper than UBER and have more drivers. However, UBERÂ drivers seem to be better trained and can read the maps so that makes it easier for us foreigners in the market.

Also, they are cheaper than UBER and have more drivers. However, UBERÂ drivers seem to be better trained and can read the maps so that makes it easier for us foreigners in the market.

post_title: Discuss: I used Grab and Uber in Myanmar. Hereâ€™s what I think they can improve on
content:
Firstly, this article was made about a comment I left on another article. The title etc is written by TiA staff and wasnâ€™t my actual thoughts as I would use an app over hailing something down most times.Â 

Secondly, I did try to add a card to Grab but it wouldnâ€™t let me on the app. Not sure if IÂ was just trying to do it at a buggy time but not being able to add a card when I wanted to means it wasnâ€™t working when I tried it.Â 

I guess my third point would be that using these apps in these new markets is totally different to say US or UK where you request a ride and the driver pulls up. 95% of the time here, you will request a ride and then the driver calls you to ask where you areâ€¦ this is where the language barrier becomes apparent. Let these big companies continue to burn VCÂ money on promos, I love the cheap rides and will bounce from whoever is offering them to whoever is offering them for the best deal, the drivers often drive for both anyway.
