The title etc is written by TiA staff and wasn't my actual thoughts as I would use an app over hailing something down most times.Â Secondly, I did try to add a card to Grab but it wouldn't let me on the app. Not sure if IÂ was just trying to do it at a buggy time but not being able to add a card when I wanted to means it wasn't working when I tried it.Â I guess my third point would be that using these apps in these new markets is totally different to say US or UK where you request a ride and the driver pulls up. 95% of the time here, you will request a ride and then the driver calls you to ask where you are... this is where the language barrier becomes apparent. Let these big companies continue to burn VCÂ money on promos, I love the cheap rides and will bounce from whoever is offering them to whoever is offering them for the best deal, the drivers often drive for both anyway.

post_title: Discuss: I used Grab and Uber in Myanmar. Hereâ€™s what I think they can improve on
content: I could address 2. and 3. as Iâ€™ve thought of them before, especially in context of Indonesia, but observed in Thailand as well.2. To get to scale in these markets, addressing the needs of out-of-towners who donâ€™t speak the language is likely a small % of the customer base. Â Payments as well â€“ while I prefer Credit card, Grab previously only used cash in Indonesia and this appeared fine for local population. In fact Uber had to pilot cash acceptance in secondary cities to enable faster customer acquisition. Now of course, both not only accept CC but Grab has a digiwallet â€˜Grabpay featureâ€™ with Top-up ability from CC/bank and special promos. (Btw I believe eventually the promos will decrease and customers will stay with one or the other based on stickiness such as money in wallet, loyalty rewards, other differentiators, but primarily logistical efficiency and service.)3. Grab actually does now have in-app translation for itâ€™s messenger, at least in Indonesia. I have often thought that Uber, or Grab and others, which has different sub fleet categories such as Uber X, Premium, etc, could develop a special â€˜Travelerâ€™ option with vetted English speaking drivers. While I no longer have personal issues with language/payment for Indonesia I recently noticed in Thailand that even though I didnâ€™t know the language, the services have developed such good processes that the driver and I could still locate each other easily enough with the precision of the map and pick-up location suggestions.

To get to scale in these markets, addressing the needs of out-of-towners who don't speak the language is likely a small % of the customer base. Â Payments as well - while I prefer Credit card, Grab previously only used cash in Indonesia and this appeared fine for local population. In fact Uber had to pilot cash acceptance in secondary cities to enable faster customer acquisition. Now of course, both not only accept CC but Grab has a digiwallet 'Grabpay feature' with Top-up ability from CC/bank and special promos. (Btw I believe eventually the promos will decrease and customers will stay with one or the other based on stickiness such as money in wallet, loyalty rewards, other differentiators, but primarily logistical efficiency and service.)3. Grab actually does now have in-app translation for it's messenger, at least in Indonesia. I have often thought that Uber, or Grab and others, which has different sub fleet categories such as Uber X, Premium, etc, could develop a special 'Traveler' option with vetted English speaking drivers. While I no longer have personal issues with language/payment for Indonesia I recently noticed in Thailand that even though I didn't know the language, the services have developed such good processes that the driver and I could still locate each other easily enough with the precision of the map and pick-up location suggestions.

You have toÂ take inspiration where you find it. Iâ€™ve started four companies and talked with hundreds of founders.Â Â Most founders, myself included, have stories of having to pull all-nighters or work insane hours to meet a deadline. Â Some say working those kinds of hours was essentialÂ to their success, andÂ some donâ€™t cite it directly.Â 

If I ever meet a successful founder who tells me that maintaining a goodÂ work-life balance was key to their success, Iâ€™ll publish it, but so far no one has ever told me that.Â

post_title: 6 life lessons from an exhausted entrepreneur
content: I have been self-employed since 2005, went through tons of failures and some success, and the worst thing to start your business is based on your passion. TheÂ truth is, nobody cares about your passion, that your dream is to travel around the worldÂ or become a millionaireâ€¦ You have to get this in your head, people are selfish and care only about themselves.Â AsÂ entrepreneurs, our job is to find out peopleâ€™s problem, offer them a solution and once they start paying you, you got a business and you scale with it. Itâ€™s quite simple actually, you donâ€™t really need to be a good salesman when you put water in front of a person who has not have water for 24 hours.
excerpt: I have been self-employed since 2005, went through tons of failures and some success, and the worst thing to start your business is based on your passion. TheÂ truth is, nobody cares about your passion, that your dream is to travel around the worldÂ or become a millionaire... You have to get this in your head, people are selfish and care only about themselves.Â AsÂ entrepreneurs, our job is to find out people's problem, offer them a solution and once they start paying you, you got a business and you scale with it. It's quite simple actually, you don't really need to be a good salesman when you put water in front of a person who has not have water for 24 hours.

content: True. You donâ€™t get paid because you do your passion, but because you do or give people something they deemÂ worthy to pay for. Whether or not thatÂ somethingÂ is your passion is irrelevant.

post_title: 6 life lessons from an exhausted entrepreneur
content:
â€œSuccessâ€”itÂ is a dream reached for by every small business owner. YetÂ it is a dream rarely realized:Â FewerÂ than 80% of small businesses in the U.S. survive their first year,Â and at five years, the survival rate drops below 50%.Â TheÂ question isâ€”why?Â  Itâ€™sÂ certainly not for a lack of sweat, enthusiasm, gumption, and grit.â€

ThisÂ is how a seeker launched a challenge at the end of 2016 on theÂ crowdsourcing platform HeroX, a challenged they called â€œPatternsÂ for Successâ€. Its purpose was to offer a better answer to thisÂ problem by providing start-ups, DIY and small business owners anÂ applicable set of tools and usefulÂ insight into strategic thinking, Â leadership, and projection of the optimism they have within.

TheÂ seeker offered a generous money award, hoping to catalyze and sourceÂ the best possible proposals from all over the world, a mission accomplished by the end of this journey.

AsÂ a former small entrepreneur I felt this out of the blueÂ challenge as a task and opportunityÂ toÂ â€œrecycleâ€ my over 13 years entrepreneurship recent past. I neverÂ believed that rough episode of my life would ever matterÂ again, in the sense that those years can still be productive and can still make some differences in other people lives.

MyÂ â€œfailureâ€ as a small entrepreneur led me to becoming a prolificÂ problem solver in open innovation marketplace/crowdsourcing and 5years later, here I was, wearing this brandÂ new hat and approaching againÂ the entrepreneurship realm with better eyes, skills and perspectives.

MyÂ proposed â€œPatterns for Successâ€ guide won the 1stÂ prize at Culture category, andÂ soon after that I wrote my first bookÂ â€œRise Above The Crowdâ€, a recently self-published book about howÂ self-redesign and a value driven approach of life directly
impacts the world, a place in words where my entrepreneurship,Â creative and problem solver lives emerge.

HopingÂ my 2 cents will level the play field, you can read for free part of myÂ writings in my Book Shop, the â€œRising Above The Crowdâ€ book is on all AmazonÂ websites.

post_title: 6 life lessons from an exhausted entrepreneur
content:
I dropped the Day Job since mid 2011, and wentÂ toÂ a place called, SmallWorld Cambodia â€“ Co-working space. I knew nothing about Entrepreneurship, Social Impact and Startup. I went there with just one intention,Â Starting Web Design Firm to make money. The first few months in SmallWorld was an amazing journey in life. I felt so much excited and less pressure. However, most people who used the space andÂ even the co-founder of that co-working space did not do anything related to building startup, but we were like playing soccer in the space, playing guitar, made crazy video and upload to Facebook,Â eating instantÂ noodle, played game,Â drink fruit shake and go home after 8pm.Â Then next time after 7am we left home again.Â Most of our neighbours thought that it would be orphanage or some small NGOÂ that work withÂ street children. Itâ€™s not the reason that we didnâ€™t want to do anything but we did not know what to do and how to run startup.Â We were like havingÂ zero knowledge about it.

I have only one website project for 3 months and theÂ money ran out before I could finish the project. Guess how much we charged?Â That was just $150/website that has more than 20 pages and a lot of dynamic content.

Since then until now I failed more than 3 startups, and lose many friends who I used to co-founded with, dropped off many jobs and lost lots of money. Life changed so much, sometimes could not even find $1 in the pocket and decided to borrow some money from other people until I found that I did not have money to pay the debt, then I took 3 to 6 months to work in any company and dropped the Job again to do another startups.Â Today, www.pengpos.comÂ is latest project.Â 

One point that I can share, Do Whatever You Love.Â When you Love it, you will find a way to survive and still persist to do it. Some people love to be working in a good company, some people loveÂ theÂ life asÂ freelancer, some people love the life as entrepreneur. Those are true love and they persist to keep doing & growing on what they love. Anyway, your experience is another good point of view. Good luck to you and your future step. ğŸ™‚

However, most people who used the space andÂ even the co-founder of that co-working space did not do anything related to building startup, but we were like playing soccer in the space, playing guitar, made crazy video and upload to Facebook,Â eating instantÂ noodle, played game,Â drink fruit shake and go home after 8pm.Â Then next time after 7am we left home again.Â Most of our neighbours thought that it would be orphanage or some small NGOÂ that work withÂ street children. Itâ€™s not the reason that we didnâ€™t want to do anything but we did not know what to do and how to run startup.Â We were like havingÂ zero knowledge about it.
I have only one website project for 3 months and theÂ money ran out before I could finish the project. Guess how much we charged?Â That was just $150/website that has more than 20 pages and a lot of dynamic content.
Since then until now I failed more than 3 startups, and lose many friends who I used to co-founded with, dropped off many jobs and lost lots of money. Life changed so much, sometimes could not even find $1 in the pocket and decided to borrow some money from other people until I found that I did not have money to pay the debt, then I took 3 to 6 months to work in any company and dropped the Job again to do another startups.Â Today, www.pengpos.comÂ is latest project.Â 
One point that I can share, Do Whatever You Love.Â When you Love it, you will find a way to survive and still persist to do it. Some people love to be working in a good company, some people loveÂ theÂ life asÂ freelancer, some people love the life as entrepreneur. Those are true love and they persist to keep doing & growing on what they love. Anyway, your experience is another good point of view. Good luck to you and your future step. ğŸ™‚

post_title: The inside story of why an explosive SaaS startup went for a quick exit with Freshworks
content: Here is what I think is behind this whole script.These folks are basically coming from Zoho and much of their model and what they are doing is providing an alternative to Zoho in the market. Many investors wanted to invest in Zoho but Zoho has positive cash flow and they are able to fund their expansions and so they have not taken any of the VCs till date. A rare feat by a startup and that too based in India. The VC community was long looking to invest in Zoho and if not what ? Fund another one that is on the same domain. The same happened with Housing.com. Â Those who were not in the â€œhousing.comâ€ bus were trying to create an alternative one to get a piece of the action. Â Hence I think Freshdesk was borne out of this problem and so many VCs have invested in it. Zarget would have found itself hard to exist because from the story it appears it just went for a game whose journey and timelineÂ was known and carved outÂ from the very start. The acquisition of â€œso manyâ€ customers etc would have been deliberate to create a story and part of the playbook that was supposed to be played and the play would end at a point as defined by the community who controlled it. So this is not a innovation or startup or value creationÂ game or was ever meant to be. Hence not worth any further discussion.Â
excerpt: Here is what I think is behind this whole script.These folks are basically coming from Zoho and much of their model and what they are doing is providing an alternative to Zoho in the market. Many investors wanted to invest in Zoho but Zoho has positive cash flow and they are able to fund their expansions and so they have not taken any of the VCs till date. A rare feat by a startup and that too based in India. The VC community was long looking to invest in Zoho and if not what ? Fund another one that is on the same domain. The same happened with Housing.com. Â Those who were not in the "housing.com" bus were trying to create an alternative one to get a piece of the action. Â Hence I think Freshdesk was borne out of this problem and so many VCs have invested in it. Zarget would have found itself hard to exist because from the story it appears it just went for a game whose journey and timelineÂ was known and carved outÂ from the very start. The acquisition of "so many" customers etc would have been deliberate to create a story and part of the playbook that was supposed to be played and the play would end at a point as defined by the community who controlled it. So this is not a innovation or startup or value creationÂ game or was ever meant to be. Hence not worth any further discussion.Â

content:
Thank you for taking time to put down your thoughts, Pulakesh.

IÂ see the point about ZohoÂ you are making butÂ beg to differ on Zargetâ€™s product. You are assuming a lot about Zarget â€œgoing for the gameâ€ and acquiring customers. Â Most SaaS founders will tell you about the struggle with churn rate. That has to do with so many externalÂ factors, including the fickleness of small-ticket size mindset (Just to take a personal example,Â I tend to experimentÂ with small purchases). So to diss a startupâ€™s product and work without spending time toÂ evaluateÂ either is not fair, I think.

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content:
Well, you can only manage what you measure, so financial metrics are absolutely key â€“ but certainly only if not taken out of context, their calculation are understood well and interpreted correctly.Â 

I donâ€™t think a startup can do w/o looking at them. Your investor â€“ if you have those -will certainly push you to deal with them. ğŸ™‚ But it is every entrepreneursâ€™ self-interest to get a handle at the most important metrics. It is part of the learning curve to deal with this dry material.Â
excerpt: Well, you can only manage what you measure, so financial metrics are absolutely key - but certainly only if not taken out of context, their calculation are understood well and interpreted correctly.Â I don't think a startup can do w/o looking at them. Your investor - if you have those -will certainly push you to deal with them. :-) But it is every entrepreneurs' self-interest to get a handle at the most important metrics. It is part of the learning curve to deal with this dry material.Â

content: Financial metrics are absolutely key â€“ but itâ€™s also a double-edged sword specially when people donâ€™t understand how to look at the bigger picture. Â (Sadly â€“ youâ€™re right, all these can be pretty dry stuff for entrepreneurs)

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: financial metrics are never pretty, but its a harsh reality that those are the top numbers any investor is going to care about when it comes to the hurdle ofÂ injecting more cash for the next big round of funding to achieve the next big milestone for a startup.Â So these numbers are justifiably important as with any other major kpis. Â I would recommend that all founders to educate themselves. Investors will smile and be more willing to trust startup founders who can provide these metrics confidently and haveÂ the understanding or comprehensionÂ to back it up.

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: You are right to say we shouldnâ€™t obsess over metrics, but onlyÂ startup that breaks even controls itâ€™s own destiny and gets to choose what metrics to measure themselves by.Â The rest live and die by whatever metrics makes them popular in the investor community â€“ and if you need funding, whatever these metrics are, most founders have no choice but to fixate over them.Â

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: Thatâ€™sÂ right. Itâ€™s quite a sad truth that thereâ€™s a lot of mismatch in understanding of accounting information in investor and finance communities. Having obsession over these metrics create a short-term focussed business vision which can forego long term business profitability. Â However, given that a lot of startup advice circles around the concept of beginning with an exit in mind (instead of running a longevity enterprise), for a lot of startup founders â€“ these metrics might be sufficient to extract quick monies from early stage exit.
excerpt: That'sÂ right. It's quite a sad truth that there's a lot of mismatch in understanding of accounting information in investor and finance communities. Having obsession over these metrics create a short-term focussed business vision which can forego long term business profitability. Â However, given that a lot of startup advice circles around the concept of beginning with an exit in mind (instead of running a longevity enterprise), for a lot of startup founders - these metrics might be sufficient to extract quick monies from early stage exit.

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content:
Only thing IÂ agree is that the lack of financial knowledge makes financial data dangerous. As for financial metrics being â€˜more noise than signal,â€™ itâ€™s complete nonsense.Â 

In any field, itâ€™s dangerous to look at only one signal for anything. In your example, you cited GPR, but you failed to cite COG, which would have given the startup managers a good indicator of profit, rather than revenue. (Why you donâ€™t talk about ratio? Because without FOMO, itâ€™s hard to get clients?)
excerpt: Only thing IÂ agree is that the lack of financial knowledge makes financial data dangerous. As for financial metrics being 'more noise than signal,' it's complete nonsense.Â In any field, it's dangerous to look at only one signal for anything. In your example, you cited GPR, but you failed to cite COG, which would have given the startup managers a good indicator of profit, rather than revenue. (Why you don't talk about ratio? Because without FOMO, it's hard to get clients?)

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content:
Thanks Roger, itâ€™s nice to have a dissenting opinion. Â Financial metrics for startup founders who are not financially savvy is more noise than signal â€“ this does not mean that for finance professionals, the same is the case. Â The problem with looking at metrics or ratios is that a lot of time, entreps can be too focussed on metrics instead of the absolute numbers â€“ which might not be applicable to you if youâ€™re looking at your business at a more holistic level.

When you said COG, I presume you meant cost of goods?, which is basically covered anyway by GPR. Â You see, thatâ€™s one point causing confusion already! I donâ€™t talk about ratios because there are better ways to look at startup financials from a professional persective not because itâ€™s difficult to get clients â€“ anyway, as I mentioned above, my Facebook page is absolutely free and I donâ€™t really charge money for insights, LOL.
excerpt: Thanks Roger, it's nice to have a dissenting opinion. Â Financial metrics for startup founders who are not financially savvy is more noise than signal - this does not mean that for finance professionals, the same is the case. Â The problem with looking at metrics or ratios is that a lot of time, entreps can be too focussed on metrics instead of the absolute numbers - which might not be applicable to you if you're looking at your business at a more holistic level.When you said COG, I presume you meant cost of goods?, which is basically covered anyway by GPR. Â You see, that's one point causing confusion already! I don't talk about ratios because there are better ways to look at startup financials from a professional persective not because it's difficult to get clients - anyway, as I mentioned above, my Facebook page is absolutely free and I don't really charge money for insights, LOL.

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: Agree somewhat. Fact is, whether u likeÂ them or not, investors wantÂ to see financial metrics. Other/better metrics do exist depending onÂ the kind of business. MetricsÂ that assess customer value are important and centralÂ to a business, among others. Nuances are indeed importantÂ to understandingÂ the health ofÂ the business, but these nuancesÂ should be addressedÂ in direct relationÂ toÂ the goals ofÂ the business.
excerpt: Agree somewhat. Fact is, whether u likeÂ them or not, investors wantÂ to see financial metrics. Other/better metrics do exist depending onÂ the kind of business. post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content:
Agree, a lot of younger investors are freshly trained from school as well which makes their approach more scholastic. Â For most seasoned investors that I have discussedÂ with, usually the focus is a lot more holistic and focussed beyond the financial metrics. Â The absolute revenue growth, EBITDA growth and free cash flow discussions comes together with focus on overall economic and business risks that affects the investee.

From your experience, what metrics and non-quantitative information do you use to judge your startupâ€™s performance?
excerpt: Agree, a lot of younger investors are freshly trained from school as well which makes their approach more scholastic. Â For most seasoned investors that I have discussedÂ with, usually the focus is a lot more holistic and focussed beyond the financial metrics. Â The absolute revenue growth, EBITDA growth and free cash flow discussions comes together with focus on overall economic and business risks that affects the investee.From your experience, what metrics and non-quantitative information do you use to judge your startup's performance?

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: I believe that thereâ€™s a sweet spot, especially for early stage startups, for the metrics that they chose. Too much metric can be a nuisance, but focusing only on one category can give you an illusion of success or growth.Â I think I speak for every founders, financial metrics are the foundation but other growth metrics acts as the fuel for the business. Its an endless process of research and experimentation to find a correct balance between those two, especially for niche sectors that has no industry standards.Â
excerpt: I believe that there's a sweet spot, especially for early stage startups, for the metrics that they chose. Too much metric can be a nuisance, but focusing only on one category can give you an illusion of success or growth.Â I think I speak for every founders, financial metrics are the foundation but other growth metrics acts as the fuel for the business. Its an endless process of research and experimentation to find a correct balance between those two, especially for niche sectors that has no industry standards.Â

post_title: Discuss: Founders are making a mistake by using financial metrics to gauge startup health
content: Thatâ€™s right â€“ However, finding the right metrics to use is a very difficult concept to grasp. Â For a lot of startup founders, having a good finance guy sitting with them would prove a worthy investment in decoding the right financial decision to go with. Â However, it always comes with a price â€“ so having a good friend is a much better solution (frequently, LOL).

post_title: Grab will pour $100m into Myanmar as it faces off with Uber
content:
Used both Uber and Grab when I was recently in Yangon. A couple of things that stood out as a foreigner using the serviceÂ which will make it hard for expansion (to target foreigners)

  • Drivers did not speak workable English. I had to pass the phone to the hotel whenever I made a booking leaving the hotel. Likewise if I was out I had to pass the phone to a staff member. I donâ€™t think I would have been able to meet the driver otherwise.Â 
  • All these services are chucking money at promotions. I was only in Yangon for a few days but I didnâ€™t pay a full fare (winning!). Great for me, but IÂ have no brand loyalty, I just chose Grab until I ran down the promo then used Uber likewise.Â 

What I liked about Uber was that they had the card payments enabled. I really didnâ€™t wanna get any more money out the ATM when I had to go to the airport, I literally just needed cash for this trip so decided to use an Uber, I read online that it was still cash only so expected to run inside the airport to get the cash for the driver but upon arriving he said it was paid for with card through the app. That made me happy!Â 

Overall not too different to the experience in Thailand with drivers not speaking English (with the added annoyance of not knowing how to use a map in Thailand).Â

All these services are chucking money at promotions. I was only in Yangon for a few days but I didnâ€™t pay a full fare (winning!). Great for me, but IÂ have no brand loyalty, I just chose Grab until I ran down the promo then used Uber likewise.Â 

What I liked about Uber was that they had the card payments enabled. I really didnâ€™t wanna get any more money out the ATM when I had to go to the airport, I literally just needed cash for this trip so decided to use an Uber, I read online that it was still cash only so expected to run inside the airport to get the cash for the driver but upon arriving he said it was paid for with card through the app. That made me happy!Â

post_title: Groupon Singapore founder is back, yet again, with a new startup
content:
Hi all, Chris Chong here.Â 

Weâ€™re using automation to streamline the PR process, not replace it. Real live humansâ€”our PR expertsâ€”are the ones who ideate, craft pitches, and analyze feedback from journalists.

We make data science work for us through assisted press scraping, matching, and lead generationâ€”at a fraction of the usual time and cost. We pass on those savings to clients, who otherwise would be unable to afford the prohibitive fees of PR firms.

In short, we use technology to make the end-to-end PRÂ process more efficient and effective. OurÂ press releases are sent to only relevant journalists identified by our matching algorithm, this differs from the traditional approach to PR â€“ the spray-and-pray tactic, which involves sending out press releases at a high volume and gaining short-lived media coverage.

Real live humansâ€”our PR expertsâ€”are the ones who ideate, craft pitches, and analyze feedback from journalists.We make data science work for us through assisted press scraping, matching, and lead generationâ€”at a fraction of the usual time and cost. OurÂ press releases are sent to only relevant journalists identified by our matching algorithm, this differs from the traditional approach to PR - the spray-and-pray tactic, which involves sending out press releases at a high volume and gaining short-lived media coverage.

post_title: I used to think bootcamp grads were unemployable, until I became their mentor
content:
The truth is that software developers become a product of what they work on.Â Â To have more varied experience they have to work on more varied things. Â But once someone works on the same thing for too long, that becomes what theyâ€™re good at. Â What I learned through teaching at bootcamps is that:Â we, as enterprise developers, tend to overly object-orient everything and a lot of work has to be completed to get anything done. Â Bootcamp grads arenâ€™t bogged down with that level of thinkingÂ (not saying its bad, just saying its aÂ tax that applies to the cost of development) and they attempt to create everything they think of in ways were it just gets done.Â Â I prefer that approach because things get done quicker and if they are profitable, can be refactored into more enterpriseâ€™y solutions later.

Iâ€™m always in the market for a good CTO gig ğŸ˜‰

Â But once someone works on the same thing for too long, that becomes what they're good at. Â What I learned through teaching at bootcamps is that:Â we, as enterprise developers, tend to overly object-orient everything and a lot of work has to be completed to get anything done. Â Bootcamp grads aren't bogged down with that level of thinkingÂ (not saying its bad, just saying its aÂ tax that applies to the cost of development) and they attempt to create everything they think of in ways were it just gets done.Â Â I prefer that approach because things get done quicker and if they are profitable, can be refactored into more enterprise'y solutions later.I'm always in the market for a good CTO gig ;)

it is about the feasibility ofÂ adopting the cashless model here for all the layman.Â 

you probably need to allocate 90% of your resources to convince the rest of the people to use. you need to research and come out ways to implement the solution so that everyone will know how to use, easy to use, want to use.

All the private commercial entities are selfish. They do their own wallet and expect people to use it so they can profit out of it.Â 

If you want fast adoption, government should intervene and â€œencourageâ€ the banking sector to collaborate and come out with a feasible solution.

there were several times, i was making payment at ntuc using dash, due to slow connection and timeoutÂ at the merchant side, the people behind feeling impatient, the cashier trying to suggest cash as alternative.

taxi drivers reluctant to use because of the hassle and the delay of payment receive from the financial institution.

stall holders in hawker center refuse to use as the cost of implementing and transaction costÂ is high. lousy connection will hold up the queue. money being held up in the â€œwalletâ€. no feasible benefit for them.

post_title: I built a chatbot in 2 hours to prove itâ€™s useless, but hereâ€™s what I learned
content:
Would disagree they are useless, people just are using them wrong. A chatbot isnâ€™t a business. It is peripheral to a business. We are building something quite cool with chatbots which will improve our customers experience 100X. We are nearly done with it and will share it when it is done. Is this bot gonna make us more money?Â No. Is it gonna save us time?Â You bet!

Chatbots arenâ€™t hard to create. IÂ have no coding skills or experience but can knock up one relatively simply. People are looking at the whole thing wrong.Â 

One of the things which I think would make a great chatbot product which would be monetizable would be to create a Sport Schedule bot. How much time do people spend wanting to find the channel that Man Utd are playing next week etc etc. This would be easy to program into a bot and then you just sell advertising to Betting companies on the FBÂ page and the web page. Super simple and Iâ€™m 100% sure it would work. If IÂ had more time Iâ€™d create that myself.Â 

Again going back to my first point, in such a product, the chatbot provides usefulness to the consumer but its super hard to monetize, whereas a bot about sports schedules would be an easy sell for betting companies. (if anyone builds this, please email me Iâ€™d love to see it ğŸ™‚ ).Â
excerpt: Would disagree they are useless, people just are using them wrong. A chatbot isn't a business. It is peripheral to a business. We are building something quite cool with chatbots which will improve our customers experience 100X. We are nearly done with it and will share it when it is done. Is this bot gonna make us more money?Â No. Is it gonna save us time?Â You bet!Chatbots aren't hard to create. IÂ have no coding skills or experience but can knock up one relatively simply. People are looking at the whole thing wrong.Â One of the things which I think would make a great chatbot product which would be monetizable would be to create a Sport Schedule bot. How much time do people spend wanting to find the channel that Man Utd are playing next week etc etc. This would be easy to program into a bot and then you just sell advertising to Betting companies on the FBÂ page and the web page. Super simple and I'm 100% sure it would work. If IÂ had more time I'd create that myself.Â Again going back to my first point, in such a product, the chatbot provides usefulness to the consumer but its super hard to monetize, whereas a bot about sports schedules would be an easy sell for betting companies. (if anyone builds this, please email me I'd love to see it :-) ).Â

post_title: A closer look into bike-sharing in China and its future
content:
Any thoughts onÂ unit economics?Â 

With directÂ costs of â€“ optimistically â€“ 45 USD per bike, when will a single bike â€˜break evenâ€™? Considering the already mentioned â€˜overheadâ€™ of maintenance, replacement, etc., I cannot see a business model that would ever work (= turning a profit eventually)Â â€“ at least not with just putting bikes in every corner.Â 

Makes me wonder why this sector is seen as attractive from a risk capital perspective: Awful unit economics withÂ very low entry barrier (imitation is easy), no lock-in/stickiness (loyalty of users is rather low)?Â 

Maybe there are some cool up-sell ideas out there where bikes become a platform for something that actually can be monetised, but at present this looks even more like a money loosing model than ride hailing apps (which have at least the advantage of not having to own/manage assets directly).Â
excerpt: Any thoughts onÂ unit economics?Â With directÂ costs of - optimistically - 45 USD per bike, when will a single bike 'break even'? Considering the already mentioned 'overhead' of maintenance, replacement, etc., I cannot see a business model that would ever work (= turning a profit eventually)Â - at least not with just putting bikes in every corner.Â Makes me wonder why this sector is seen as attractive from a risk capital perspective: Awful unit economics withÂ very low entry barrier (imitation is easy), no lock-in/stickiness (loyalty of users is rather low)?Â Maybe there are some cool up-sell ideas out there where bikes become a platform for something that actually can be monetised, but at present this looks even more like a money loosing model than ride hailing apps (which have at least the advantage of not having to own/manage assets directly).Â

post_title: A closer look into bike-sharing in China and its future
content: Great point! Have been thinking about this too â€“ I think that the core metric to watch would be averageÂ daily rides per market. The more daily rides there are, the more revenues they can achieve.Â The cost factorsÂ are cost of bicycle production, shipping, servicing, relocation etc. I believe that at a certain average daily rides no. in every market, there will be an inflection point to profitability.Â

post_title: Why a proper sales engine is very important to both startups and big companies
content:
Step 1. Extremely painful problem that you make a solution to solve

Step 2. THEN build the sales engine.

Nothing worse then seeing a startup with a team of 4+ marketing/sales guys wasting their time every day because there is zero product fit. Probably actively negative effect on the business that the startup is actively paying for in the form of salaries. Sales/marketing people canâ€™t do shit to sell a product that is looking for a problem.

post_title: Southeast Asiaâ€™s â€˜funding barbellâ€™ spurs new Gobi Partners fund
content:
Hmm Series AÂ always a tricky oneâ€¦ business is usually making some revenue, but itâ€™s not yet proven to be something that can exponentially expand (facing market barriers, user acquisition cost issues, etc..). During a Seed, investor can put in comparatively little for a large stake in the companyâ€¦ at that point if things donâ€™t pan out, itâ€™s easy to write it off as a full loss.

Series A though, requiring a much more substantial investment, seems to be at that point that investors are not really able to â€œwrite offâ€ a loss. It seems instead, investors simply donâ€™t participate in the Series A, and just wait for Series B+ where revenue and growth rate is usually â€œlocked inâ€.

Makes sense.
excerpt: Hmm Series AÂ always a tricky one... business is usually making some revenue, but it's not yet proven to be something that can exponentially expand (facing market barriers, user acquisition cost issues, etc..). During a Seed, investor can put in comparatively little for a large stake in the company... at that point if things don't pan out, it's easy to write it off as a full loss.Series A though, requiring a much more substantial investment, seems to be at that point that investors are not really able to "write off" a loss. It seems instead, investors simply don't participate in the Series A, and just wait for Series B+ where revenue and growth rate is usually "locked in".Makes sense.

post_title: Alibaba leads $1.1b investment in Indonesiaâ€™s Tokopedia
content: I think Alibaba realizes that Indonesia will be its own battleground within SEAÂ and needs a focused strategy. And letting JD (which is also gaining marketshare in B2C in China) get Tokopedia would have made life challenging for Alibabaâ€™s expansion plans. My guess would be Lazada will pull out of Indonesia, focusing instead on the rest of SEA. With Amazon starting off in Singapore and MY, Lazada has its work cut out.Â Regardless of what Alibaba claimed in its earning call about Lazadaâ€™s continuous growth, they didnâ€™t breakdown Lazadaâ€™s revenue, instead clubbing it withÂ Aliexpress. Considering how huge AliExpress has been for a while, a combined $340m revenue isnâ€™t staggering.Â More interesting would be to see where Alibaba exerts more control. Rocket guys are great at planting seeds in new markets, but when it comes to competing at scale against more formidable opponents with resources and ability to innovateÂ that Amazon and JD has, Rocketeers are fundamentally not equipped to handle. So yeah my bet, a lot of changes in Lazada are expected.
excerpt: I think Alibaba realizes that Indonesia will be its own battleground within SEAÂ and needs a focused strategy. And letting JD (which is also gaining marketshare in B2C in China) get Tokopedia would have made life challenging for Alibaba's expansion plans. My guess would be Lazada will pull out of Indonesia, focusing instead on the rest of SEA. With Amazon starting off in Singapore and MY, Lazada has its work cut out.Â Regardless of what Alibaba claimed in its earning call about Lazada's continuous growth, they didn't breakdown Lazada's revenue, instead clubbing it withÂ Aliexpress. Considering how huge AliExpress has been for a while, a combined $340m revenue isn't staggering.Â More interesting would be to see where Alibaba exerts more control. Rocket guys are great at planting seeds in new markets, but when it comes to competing at scale against more formidable opponents with resources and ability to innovateÂ that Amazon and JD has, Rocketeers are fundamentally not equipped to handle. So yeah my bet, a lot of changes in Lazada are expected.

Many peopleÂ are buying with hopes of the appreciation of the underlying asset, but thatâ€™s not the true original purpose of a tokenÂ â€“ the token system was built to create a means to do things like game items, loyalty points, etc.

Weâ€™re building a system where a token = a ticket to take the ride on our ad network, and doing a pre-sale of these tokens as a means of crowdfunding the shift from a traditional ad network to a blockchain-powered network.Â

post_title: What I learned building a mobile payments app in Singapore and facing DBS
content:
I read an article recently that stated point blank that itâ€™s going to get harder for startups over the coming years due to these same issues that you spell out here. Namely that large pre-established companies have the resources to overcome the initialÂ difficulties with customer adoption through straight dumping cash on them. This, IÂ suppose, is why so many startups, especially the unicorns, are throwing metric tons of cash at their client base to take market share (hundreds of millions of $$).

You can bet as a startup you arenâ€™t going to compete with that.Â 

I think in Asia this problem is worse than America because the systems here cater more towards big businesses. As you said, you didnâ€™t have any APIs/open x/y/z available and were at a disadvantage from the startâ€¦ itâ€™s the same thing in Korea, Japan, etcâ€¦

Iâ€™m much more of a fan of â€œstartupsâ€ that are actually just small businesses aiming to fill a niche and slowly grow out a brand/customer baseâ€¦ â€œhockystick growthâ€ and â€œdistruptiveâ€ cash burning startups.. yea, not so interesting.
excerpt: I read an article recently that stated point blank that it's going to get harder for startups over the coming years due to these same issues that you spell out here. Namely that large pre-established companies have the resources to overcome the initialÂ difficulties with customer adoption through straight dumping cash on them. This, IÂ suppose, is why so many startups, especially the unicorns, are throwing metric tons of cash at their client base to take market share (hundreds of millions of $$).You can bet as a startup you aren't going to compete with that.Â I think in Asia this problem is worse than America because the systems here cater more towards big businesses. As you said, you didn't have any APIs/open x/y/z available and were at a disadvantage from the start... it's the same thing in Korea, Japan, etc...I'm much more of a fan of "startups" that are actually just small businesses aiming to fill a niche and slowly grow out a brand/customer base... "hockystick growth" and "distruptive" cash burning startups.. yea, not so interesting.

post_title: What I learned building a mobile payments app in Singapore and facing DBS
content:
cashless is the trend, and its a good idea to start aÂ startup in payment industry. Im in the payment industry too and I can feel suffering during this journey which always happens when doing startup. The best thing is you guys have learned a lot from this experience which you will never get from working as an employer. It seems the finalÂ decision to quit was becauseÂ DBS PayLah joined this game. We have been working with many payment companies all over the world, however,Â most of them are not run by the traditional banks, and the most successful payment giants like paypal or alipay are not run by the banks too even the banks have much money, and I believe its likely the banks canâ€™t compete with startups when coming to payment industry. Just feel some pity for quitting in short time.

Regarding high barriers for payment industry, as youÂ said, there are no banking api available and card processing fees are high. I have to say they are not friendly indeed, but thats equal for all companies even for the banks. Regarding the card processing fees, youÂ mentioned the fees are capped at 0.2% by regulators in UK, which is not correct.Â 0.2% is only for the interchange fee, and the total fees for most merchants in North America and Europe are 2-4%. You can refer to stripe or paymill for the pricing. Venmo charges 3% if the users use credit card to pay, and Venmo encourages the users to use debit card or bank transfer in order to keep the fees low. So the card processing fees are high for all companies in the world. The disadvantage is no direct banking api for Singapore, but you can still use eNets (well, eNets is not so friendly too), anyway, it should not be the key point. Chinese banks have no banking api at the beginning, however, the banks madeÂ their api available when they found online e-commerce are growing soÂ fast.

I think the biggestÂ barrier is how you can get enough merchants and users at the beginning. You know, its a marketplace model like Uber, with both of sellers and buyers involved. You will have to get enough merchants before attracting your users to use your e-wallet, and there must be good enough users before persuading the merchants to offer your e-wallet as a payment option. Its very difficult to get good enough volume on both sides, especially at the beginning.

Â Paypal and Alipay started with online payments when the merchants have few options to collect online payments. Most merchants prefer to use them because they have no better options, so its not difficult for them to get their first merchants. They use their merchants to get their users, and then grow as the online e-commerce market grows. They start to come to offlineÂ when they become giant and many people are used to using them. However, you guys started with offline business first, which makes it moreÂ difficult whenÂ SingaporeÂ people are used to using cash or card for offline shopping and eating.

We have been working with many payment companies all over the world, however,Â most of them are not run by the traditional banks, and the most successful payment giants like paypal or alipay are not run by the banks too even the banks have much money, and I believe its likely the banks can't compete with startups when coming to payment industry. post_title: What I learned building a mobile payments app in Singapore and facing DBS
content:
Thanks for the well-wishes Sebastian.

To answer your queries, we did not seek to equip merchants with smartphones & data plan because that would make for an unsustainable business both short- and long-term. The usage of PayPal was out of the question for us because of the fees: 3.9% +$0.50 works out to be 20.6% fees for a $3 meal. None of the merchants would be willing to pay 20.6% fees just for cashless payment collection, and it also defeats our goal of trying to engineer a low-cost payment solution.

As for your comments on NUS, I can share that NUS is a large organization with sub-divisions each having different agendas. The Office that introduced DBS PayLah into the ecosystem was trying to advance their cashless agenda in what they believe would be the fastest way, since DBS has the resources to incentivize consumer behaviour. Hope this explains.

The usage of PayPal was out of the question for us because of the fees: 3.9% +$0.50 works out to be 20.6% fees for a $3 meal. None of the merchants would be willing to pay 20.6% fees just for cashless payment collection, and it also defeats our goal of trying to engineer a low-cost payment solution.As for your comments on NUS, I can share that NUS is a large organization with sub-divisions each having different agendas. The Office that introduced DBS PayLah into the ecosystem was trying to advance their cashless agenda in what they believe would be the fastest way, since DBS has the resources to incentivize consumer behaviour. Hope this explains.

post_title: Discuss: Resist the urge to copy your competitor even if theyâ€™re a lot bigger than you
content:
facebook has built a robust testing infrastructure and has the scale to test anything before launching. If they choose to test a new featureÂ only onÂ 0.1% Â of their users, thatâ€™s 2 million users. Thatâ€™s good enough for them to know whether a new feature is working out our not. So, itâ€™s hard for FB to fail big.Â 

This luxury of scale is somethingÂ most startups donâ€™t have. Hence, building your own stuff and incrementally developing your differentiators is the most robust easy to go. You should be aware of what others are doing, but never blatently copy!Â
excerpt: facebook has built a robust testing infrastructure and has the scale to test anything before launching. If they choose to test a new featureÂ only onÂ 0.1% Â of their users, that's 2 million users. That's good enough for them to know whether a new feature is working out our not. So, it's hard for FB to fail big.Â This luxury of scale is somethingÂ most startups don't have. Hence, building your own stuff and incrementally developing your differentiators is the most robust easy to go. You should be aware of what others are doing, but never blatently copy!Â

If youâ€™re afraid of competition, you shouldnâ€™t even build a company because you will eventually fail following your competition too closely.Â 

I like this statement. Preparation might be way better than fear.Â But whatâ€™s the best way for entrepreneursÂ toÂ prepare if theyâ€™ll be going up against big players, especially in a saturated market?
excerpt: If youâ€™re afraid of competition, you shouldnâ€™t even build a company because you will eventually fail following your competition too closely.Â I like this statement. Preparation might be way better than fear.Â But what's the best way for entrepreneursÂ toÂ prepare if they'll be going up against big players, especially in a saturated market?

post_title: Discuss: Resist the urge to copy your competitor even if theyâ€™re a lot bigger than you
content:
But whatâ€™s the best way for entrepreneurs to prepare if theyâ€™ll be going up against big players, especially in a saturated market? Â 

Then donâ€™t start in a saturated market. You will have no advantage but massive disadvantagesÂ there, with big players/barriers here and there. Start in a small, relatively empty market, where you can be a dominant player. After that you can scale up. Read Zero to One, itâ€™s good for entrepreneurÂ wannabes like us ğŸ™‚

Just remember this quote: better be number one in a village than being number 1000 in Rome.

In case you are wondering about Google and Facebook, do remember that their products and services areÂ way betterÂ than their competitorsâ€™. For example, Googleâ€™s Search Engine is miles ahead of Yahooâ€™s, and Facebook is way better than Friendster orÂ MySpace. So if you are very confident in your product, for being significantly superior than what current big players have, then you can start in that saturated market. Of course, thatâ€™s a bigÂ IF.

post_title: Data science simplified: Simple linear regression models
content:
Thanks Imam. TheÂ t statisticÂ is theÂ coefficientÂ divided by itsÂ standard error.Â The standard error is an estimate of theÂ standard deviationÂ of the coefficient, the amount it varies across cases. It can be thought of as a measure of the precision with which the regression coefficient is measured. If standard error is low, larger the value of t-stat implying that there is stronger relation between dependent and independent variable.

If you are keen to lookout for more of my posts, you can start following my blog:Â https://datascientia.blog/

There are two more posts on Data Science Simplified series.

post_title: These shocking hidden terms of â€˜SAFEâ€™ notes can screw up your startup
content:
Does Accelerator termsÂ Â even matter at the series A level.Â 

Any A investor worth its salt, will ask every one including angels and AcceleratorsÂ to fall inÂ line, drop the crazy liquidation pref and other rights and sign a standard SHA.Â Mostly they will be pushed to to common shares or bought out.

So most of these are academic in nature if you raised next round of funding.Â 

But yes i have seen VC whose knowledge of terms and understanding of legal docs are questionableÂ and they screw founders siding the accelerators.Â Â God help those investments.
excerpt: Does Accelerator termsÂ Â even matter at the series A level.Â Any A investor worth its salt, will ask every one including angels and AcceleratorsÂ to fall inÂ line, drop the crazy liquidation pref and other rights and sign a standard SHA.Â Mostly they will be pushed to to common shares or bought out.So most of these are academic in nature if you raised next round of funding.Â But yes i have seen VC whose knowledge of terms and understanding of legal docs are questionableÂ and they screw founders siding the accelerators.Â Â God help those investments.

post_title: These shocking hidden terms of â€˜SAFEâ€™ notes can screw up your startup
content:
Some assumptions here:

1. Most companies in SEA do not go on to raise a Series A after an accelerator round. Usually they end up raising on more notes. Hence even more trouble.

2. Series A investors donâ€™t do secondary buyouts of angels and accelerators. This is not the US. Even US doesnâ€™t do secondary sales that early.

3. You are assuming the accelerator is willing to play ball later. In most cases I have seen this not to be the case. The company signed the terms with the accelerator and technically the accelerator money and program helped the company get to its current state, so I donâ€™t see why you can justify the accelerator to renegotiate the Greemeent that easily
excerpt:
Some assumptions here:

1. Most companies in SEA do not go on to raise a Series A after an accelerator round. Usually they end up raising on more notes. Hence even more trouble.

2. Series A investors don't do secondary buyouts of angels and accelerators. This is not the US. Even US doesn't do secondary sales that early.

3. You are assuming the accelerator is willing to play ball later. In most cases I have seen this not to be the case. The company signed the terms with the accelerator and technically the accelerator money and program helped the company get to its current state, so I don't see why you can justify the accelerator to renegotiate the Greemeent that easily

post_title: Our unexpected long journey pivoting from digital agency to product company
content: Thanks Steven. One of the things I didnâ€™t mention in my original article is that, from 2004, we have also had an office in Bangkok (which is run by Luke), so we have a great affinity with the region. All of the staff in the original Codegent Bangkok team are now fully-engaged on ScreenCloud.For us, it felt like the right move and now, as ScreenCloud continues to grow, we know that focusing on one thing and making it the best it can be, was a good decision. Having said that, IÂ think the agency model is evolving too, with more of them looking at different models to monetise their IP. One of ScreenCloudâ€™s investors is R/GA, who is an international agency that has set up a Venture Studio and invests in a small cohort of startups every year. This allows them to be at the cutting edge of emerging technologies, which in turn means that they can talk with authority to their clients about what might be on the horizon.Â

This allows them to be at the cutting edge of emerging technologies, which in turn means that they can talk with authority to their clients about what might be on the horizon.Â

post_title: Payfazz is the first Indonesian startup to make it into Y Combinator
content:
Hi Rick,

PAYFAZZ has been live for 8-9 months now, we acquired those agents through digital marketing during this time. The agent top up/get balance from PAYFAZZ by doing bank transfer. One of the requirement to be PAYFAZZ Agent who will serve unbanked around them is to have a bank account. If they donâ€™t have it, we guide them to open one.

Thanks ğŸ™‚
excerpt:
Hi Rick,

PAYFAZZ has been live for 8-9 months now, we acquired those agents through digital marketing during this time. The agent top up/get balance from PAYFAZZ by doing bank transfer. One of the requirement to be PAYFAZZ Agent who will serve unbanked around them is to have a bank account. If they don't have it, we guide them to open one.

Thanks :)

post_title: Data science simplified: Hypothesis testing with Isildur and Gandalf

post_title: Why Tim Cook is â€œvery, very bullish and very, very optimisticâ€ on made-in-India iPhones
content:
It was a good article nevertheless it would have been better if you had also added your personal comments on the issue. I feel thatÂ Tim is caught in a soup here.Â 

iPhones used to be $800+/phone and used to cater to a market which is now being taken by the Chinese(One+, Vivo, Oppo) as the customers have an option to bring down their budget and yet have a competitive phone.Â Meanwhile, Apple canâ€™t bring the costs of its phones to $200-400Â because if it does that it loses the loyal big-ticket size customers as it takes away the exclusivity of Apple(flaunt toys) from those people.Other than that if Apple wants to compete Mi(Xioami), it better be ready because the Chinese know their game well and will beat them in every quarters.Thus ignoring what Tim has to say, Apple is just adding its manufacturing units to India and want to add to its Chinese manufacturing units. â€˜Make in Indiaâ€™ has got nothing to do with it.
excerpt: It was a good article nevertheless it would have been better if you had also added your personal comments on the issue. I feel thatÂ Tim is caught in a soup here.Â iPhones used to be $800+/phone and used to cater to a market which is now being taken by the Chinese(One+, Vivo, Oppo) as the customers have an option to bring down their budget and yet have a competitive phone.Â Meanwhile, Apple can't bring the costs of its phones to $200-400Â because if it does that it loses the loyal big-ticket size customers as it takes away the exclusivity of Apple(flaunt toys) from those people.Other than that if Apple wants to compete Mi(Xioami), it better be ready because the Chinese know their game well and will beat them in every quarters.Thus ignoring what Tim has to say, Apple is just adding its manufacturing units to India and want to add to its Chinese manufacturing units. 'Make in India' has got nothing to do with it.

content: In a traditional startup, one has toÂ bootstrap for at least 1-2Â years before it can start to exist as aÂ business. Not many top talents from good local and overseasÂ universities would be willing to take the risk. Also VCs only fund those who have the potential to getÂ at least 10-100Â billion rupiah ofÂ annual revenues which excludes the vast majority of startups.Â I have met quite a few foreign graduates (especially those who donâ€™t have to inherit family business)Â who claimed that they have founded a startup but ended up joining aÂ company associated directly or indirectlyÂ with one of the conglomerates (hence the term â€œintrapreneurâ€).Â Â If one has the passion and skill (withÂ some creativity) in one particular area, Â willing to explore beyond oneâ€™s comfort zone (the saying birds of the same color flock togetherÂ especially resonatesÂ veryÂ stronglyÂ here inÂ class-consciousÂ Indonesia), and willing to live simply for at leastÂ few yearsÂ and work hard, there are stillÂ pockets ofÂ opportunities in theÂ overlooked, nichey, less-sexyÂ areasÂ which canÂ earn a decent living.

post_title: How to tell if an employee should be fired
content:
Hi Kate,

Thank you for the feedback.

The article shares about some considerations for employers to takeÂ when deciding if an employee should be let go, and offers employers another perspective to think about before letting an employee go.Â 

Employers generally do not want to let their employees go and many would fight for employees to stay as time and effort had been put in to grooming an employee. However, there are situations where employers are forced to show their hand and it is not always pleasant.Â 

Through this article, we also hope to share these so that employees have in mind some idea on lines which should not be crossed, and result in these situations.

Please feel free to also add in your ideas on how to keep employees away from ever reaching such situations ğŸ™‚

One of my employees has constantly been telling me that he wants to leave because he is not enjoying himself and wants something meaty to do. When given meaty projects to handle, he constantly expects to be told the next steps (a bit too much actually)- I was hoping a sense of ownership would push him to go out and implement the same but it ends up eating so much of my time that I sometimes think I shouldnâ€™t have had to put someone else on the job!

post_title: Why I chose to base my company in the Philippines, and not in Singapore or Hong Kong
content:
Well written article, Mario. As a local entrepreneur based in DavaoÂ City, of all places, I found the Filipino environment challenging and exciting at the same time. The opportunity for growth are substantial, yet letâ€™s not forget that the government is capping the percentage of domestic (= Philippine)Â revenues a foreign-owned company can extract.

This wasÂ probably meant to boost the export-driven service companies like BPOs but itâ€™s stifling the ability of foreign players to sellÂ their uniqueÂ expertise to local businesses.

We will see how things evolve in the next few years. All in all, the Philippines are indeed an interesting place to be, for a foreigner to try a business.

In bocca al lupo!

Well written article, Mario. As a local entrepreneur based in DavaoÂ City, of all places, I found the Filipino environment challenging and exciting at the same time. The opportunity for growth are substantial, yet letâ€™s not forget that the government is capping the percentage of domestic (= Philippine)Â revenues a foreign-owned company can extract.
This wasÂ probably meant to boost the export-driven service companies like BPOs but itâ€™s stifling the ability of foreign players to sellÂ their uniqueÂ expertise to local businesses.
We will see how things evolve in the next few years. All in all, the Philippines are indeed an interesting place to be, for a foreigner to try a business.

post_title: Discuss: There are really only 2 ways your startup will get rich
content:

Definitely agree with this. Iâ€™ve read about too many startup failures that could have been avoided if more thought had gone into making revenue.
excerpt: Iâ€™ve had conversations with startup founders who have built an app or a website, have grown their user base, and are now â€œsearching for a business model."Definitely agree with this. I've read about too many startup failures that could have been avoided if more thought had gone into making revenue.

post_title: Discuss: There are really only 2 ways your startup will get rich
content:
I agree that a businesses revenue stream would be A or B. However, IÂ also believe that while a company may clearly know very well what they sell, they may not always be aware of what their customers are buying from them.Â 

I think this lack of insight and reflection on their business can result in the company being diverted from their core-strenghts and focus. For example, while one may say that Uber offers a taxi service, what their customers are buying is convenience and hassle free travel.Â 

In my experience, companies that come into a market with a â€œme-tooâ€ product (copying a market leader) for a neglected market segment, their business decisions are not to improve what their customers are buying from them instead it is to improve their share of the market (which they ultimately lose because they are working to improve what their customers are buying)

Would like to hear others thoughts on this too.
excerpt: I agree that a businesses revenue stream would be A or B. However, IÂ also believe that while a company may clearly know very well what they sell, they may not always be aware of what their customers are buying from them.Â I think this lack of insight and reflection on their business can result in the company being diverted from their core-strenghts and focus. For example, while one may say that Uber offers a taxi service, what their customers are buying is convenience and hassle free travel.Â In my experience, companies that come into a market with a "me-too" product (copying a market leader) for a neglected market segment, their business decisions are not to improve what their customers are buying from them instead it is to improve their share of the market (which they ultimately lose because they are working to improve what their customers are buying)Would like to hear others thoughts on this too.

post_title: Discuss: There are really only 2 ways your startup will get rich
content: Yeah you need to find product-market fit by knowing who your customers are and what they want/need.Â Me-too strategy sucks, you need to differentiate products so that they have unique values that competitorsâ€™ products do not possess. Otherwise thereâ€™s no logic in choosing your product over (stronger, older)Â competitorâ€™s.
excerpt: Yeah you need to find product-market fit by knowing who your customers are and what they want/need.Â Me-too strategy sucks, you need to differentiate products so that they have unique values that competitors' products do not possess. Otherwise there's no logic in choosing your product over (stronger, older)Â competitor's.

post_title: Facebookâ€™s fierce growth in Asia is beginning to slow
content: The compounded growth rates for the world, Asia, and the rest of the world are 2.95%, 4.16% and 3.71% respectively. I think itâ€™s possible that while Asian user growth falls, monetisation can increase, while user growth in the rest of the world takes up the slack. Although I wonder if the presence of large B2C players such as Lazada may prove an obstacle to monetisation as their ability to outspend smaller players in ad auctions hinder their growth, and the small players will be unable to match their spending which would drive up ad auction values.
excerpt: The compounded growth rates for the world, Asia, and the rest of the world are 2.95%, 4.16% and 3.71% respectively. I think it's possible that while Asian user growth falls, monetisation can increase, while user growth in the rest of the world takes up the slack. Although I wonder if the presence of large B2C players such as Lazada may prove an obstacle to monetisation as their ability to outspend smaller players in ad auctions hinder their growth, and the small players will be unable to match their spending which would drive up ad auction values.

post_title: Indiaâ€™s top food delivery startup accused of cheating. Swiggy returns fire, calls it a lie
content:
Some great points made here. Fabrications on revenue/spreadsheets to investors = par for the course, especially in developing countries like India where fighting legal battles between investors and entrepreneurs (especially foreign investors), is just a massive waste of time and money.

Aggressive business tactics, while immoral, seems like a sound business decision by Swiggy management. Sure, itâ€™s abusive as fuck, but guess what, no-one in power cares. Get in with a â€œtoo good to be trueâ€ offer to a restaurant, hit them with your brand and â€œeveryone else is doing itâ€, and then over a few months screw them over little by little.

This is *exactly* the same business model used by the majority of Chinese manufacturers, especially during the high days of Americans falling over themselves to establish manufacturing in China to out-compete rivalsâ€¦ Lure the idiot foreigners in with â€œtoo good to be trueâ€ deals and cheap labor, and then over months and years, fade out the quality of the product to wring as much $$ as possible out of your â€œpartnerâ€.

Personally, I hate business like this and think the decision makers who went along with it should be crucified. However, thatâ€™s just the way the world is â€“ again â€“ ESPECIALLY in countries like India where screwing others over really is par for the course.

I canâ€™t help believing that a majority of the investors who decided to go along with the Swiggy ride were expecting fabrication of revenues, along with business tactics designed to maximize market gain, individual business owners be damned. Plus, investing in an Indian company.. am I really expecting their team to be 100% upfront with what they are saying to me? Probably not.

Fabrications on revenue/spreadsheets to investors = par for the course, especially in developing countries like India where fighting legal battles between investors and entrepreneurs (especially foreign investors), is just a massive waste of time and money.Aggressive business tactics, while immoral, seems like a sound business decision by Swiggy management. Sure, it's abusive as fuck, but guess what, no-one in power cares. Get in with a "too good to be true" offer to a restaurant, hit them with your brand and "everyone else is doing it", and then over a few months screw them over little by little.This is *exactly* the same business model used by the majority of Chinese manufacturers, especially during the high days of Americans falling over themselves to establish manufacturing in China to out-compete rivals... Lure the idiot foreigners in with "too good to be true" deals and cheap labor, and then over months and years, fade out the quality of the product to wring as much $$ as possible out of your "partner".Personally, I hate business like this and think the decision makers who went along with it should be crucified. However, that's just the way the world is - again - ESPECIALLY in countries like India where screwing others over really is par for the course.I can't help believing that a majority of the investors who decided to go along with the Swiggy ride were expecting fabrication of revenues, along with business tactics designed to maximize market gain, individual business owners be damned. Plus, investing in an Indian company.. am I really expecting their team to be 100% upfront with what they are saying to me? Probably not.

post_title: Indiaâ€™s top food delivery startup accused of cheating. Swiggy returns fire, calls it a lie
content:
Lets not restrict ethics only toÂ the F&B. Take the example of any industry, and this practices are very common, not only in India but across the globe. Whoever has the customer [buying power] will demandÂ the terms. You can take example of big manufacturers [brands] who kill the retailers with lowest possible margin bcaz customers comes and buys the Brand. If there is demand created for â€œsomethingâ€, the owners will definitely try to capitalize on that.

On Private Label, this is again a very common trend with the retailers across the globe. Any retailer who has a customer base, sees the fast moving product and creates his own private label. This can be seen in context to my first point, where brands do not give enough margins to sustain and retailer has to find alternate source of income. He is taking the risk by doing so, which should also pay him back.

Would not comment on forging the numbers, as believing either party is without proof is not right.

content: Interesting angle for job matching. I just hope corps donâ€™t exploitÂ low-wage workers post graduation. Despite smallÂ overall unemployment, ~40% of Japanâ€™s workforce is non-contract. The days of â€œlifetime employmentâ€ are waning, and companies are increasingly hiring irregular workers to cut staffing costs. The gig economy is great for students, but when theyâ€™re older/if they have mouths to feed, regular employment with benefits and PTO is essential.

The gig economy is great for students, but when they're older/if they have mouths to feed, regular employment with benefits and PTO is essential.

post_title: They came from France to help Japanese students score their next job
content:
100%Â agree Quigley. Btw, good to see you here.

Irregular work, even if well paid, is just a massive burden to deal with when you have a family to take care of and support. That feeling of not knowing where the next paycheck will come from and the difficulties of not having any benefits really does have a huge effect on happiness and life.

From the business perspective though, I have known a few companies, personally, that juice internships and contract workers for every cent of productive work they can get, then throw them away when they are not useful. Itâ€™s just not a moral way to run a business.

That feeling of not knowing where the next paycheck will come from and the difficulties of not having any benefits really does have a huge effect on happiness and life.From the business perspective though, I have known a few companies, personally, that juice internships and contract workers for every cent of productive work they can get, then throw them away when they are not useful. It's just not a moral way to run a business.

post_title: Building a hardware startup: Getting logistics and finance right
content: Youâ€™re welcome Daniel!Â We donâ€™t ship our products from Singapore. We do it from Hong Kong. So we setup the warehouse there and work with Easyship as the logistics service provider. We work with them because they have good customer service. We chose Hong Kong because itâ€™s closer to our factory, thus lowering logistics cost to get to our warehouse. Hong Kong also doesnâ€™t have sales taxes, which was a major factor whereas Singapore has GST.

post_title: Video: China shows off self-driving patrol boat
content:
Keep wondering why places like Americaâ€™s border with mexico, and sea-based areas where you need constant patrols havenâ€™t already rolled out automated drones/boats already.

Itâ€™s ridiculously inexpensive to mass-manufacture drones at scale, and each one could cover, if air based, tens of kilometers of area using this-gen thermal/IR camera imagery.

Compared to paying boats full of patrol-men to waste time boating around (or walking around) border/patrol areas, itâ€™s just insanely cheap.

Guess there is a push back similar to the American airforce where pilots and the commanders in charge of them actively resist change simply due to wanting to keep jobs and avoid â€œlayingâ€ people off?

*sigh*

post_title: Deck your pitch with slides to impress
content:
Pitch deck essentials :

  1. Company PurposeÂ â€“ Your mission and vision. Keep this slide short and punchy
  2. TeamÂ â€“ Introduce your key personnel and their track records
  3. ProblemÂ â€“ What problem are you trying to solve?
  4. SolutionÂ â€“ How your product or business solves the problem
  5. OpportunityÂ â€“ Why the iron is hot and investors should strike now
  6. Target market & distributionÂ â€“ Define your target consumers
  7. Total addressable marketÂ â€“ Show how you calculate the market
  8. ProductÂ â€“ Key features and the all-important demo
  9. Business ModelÂ â€“ How youâ€™re going to make people give up their hard-earned money
  10. CompetitionÂ â€“ A perceptual map on how you are positioned compared to your rivals
  11. (a) Seed & above: TractionÂ â€“ What progress youâ€™ve already made
    (b) Preseed: 5-year planÂ â€“ Include strategic plans for your startup
  12. Fund usageÂ â€“ How much are you raising? What will the funds be spent on?
  13. Exit strategyÂ â€“ Identify companies that may be interested in acquiring you in the futureÂ 
  14. Thanks for the ideas.. ğŸ˜€
excerpt:
Pitch deck essentials :Company PurposeÂ â€“ Your mission and vision. Keep this slide short and punchyTeamÂ â€“ Introduce your key personnel and their track recordsProblemÂ â€“ What problem are you trying to solve?SolutionÂ â€“ How your product or business solves the problemOpportunityÂ â€“ Why the iron is hot and investors should strike nowTarget market & distributionÂ â€“ Define your target consumersTotal addressable marketÂ â€“ Show how you calculate the marketProductÂ â€“ Key features and the all-important demoBusiness ModelÂ â€“ How youâ€™re going to make people give up their hard-earned moneyCompetitionÂ â€“ A perceptual map on how you are positioned compared to your rivals(a) Seed & above: TractionÂ â€“ What progress youâ€™ve already made
(b) Preseed: 5-year planÂ â€“ Include strategic plans for your startupFund usageÂ â€“ How much are you raising? What will the funds be spent on?Exit strategyÂ â€“ Identify companies that may be interested in acquiring you in the futureÂ Thanks for the ideas.. :D

post_title: Video: The AR office of the not-too-distant future
content: In my opinion I would love to have such technology.However, basing on the video just now, one drawback would be dizziness. I believe after a days work with the current iteration of the system you would be left a bit seasick amidst the constant jitters of the screen.Imagine a bumpy ride on the bus while reading a book or an article on your phone. A bit nauseating but bearable. Now imagine doing that with more screens or more books all at the same time.Looking forward on them improving the stability of the feed. I believe better sensors or software would be of great help.
