post_title: The worst ways to leave your developer job
content: Definitely, feel that this article is kind of a sponsored one from the people who are sitting as employers and want to indirectly manipulate developers,Â to be developers or to be entrepreneurs. Techinasia is a platform where definitely both developers and to be entrepreneurs come and not already established owners of a software company. So it is in their best interest to float these kinds of theories and point by point reasons of indirect threatening about a developers future. Well people its like a relationship if you do not reciprocate respect for people working with or for you, you are destined to be left in the lurk. Â But still some people will say â€œIt is better to eat your ego, rather than having shit to eatâ€, this again is a threat of indirect kind, and where it comes from we all should know by now, the people who call themselves masters (employers)Â and us slaves (employees). If the developers are so important that their work canâ€™t be picked up easily by a new person, then start respecting and monetarily recognizing them, if monetary aspect is a problem for a company in present, then give the developer an equity, he will be more than happy in making you succeed rather than just working or changing for salary hikes. If the employers are not even ready for this and still want you to continue than thatâ€™s a red flag about their intentions, which means they will throw you out and hire a cheaper resource for support once the actual creative software development job is done, to make some extra bucks. Something similar happened in US when outsourcing started to India, and it is repeating itself now when Indian develpers are getting replaced by cheaper options. My suggestion is go for the money until you find someone worthy of your presence in their team.
excerpt: Definitely, feel that this article is kind of a sponsored one from the people who are sitting as employers and want to indirectly manipulate developers,Â to be developers or to be entrepreneurs. Techinasia is a platform where definitely both developers and to be entrepreneurs come and not already established owners of a software company. So it is in their best interest to float these kinds of theories and point by point reasons of indirect threatening about a developers future. Well people its like a relationship if you do not reciprocate respect for people working with or for you, you are destined to be left in the lurk. Â But still some people will say "It is better to eat your ego, rather than having shit to eat", this again is a threat of indirect kind, and where it comes from we all should know by now, the people who call themselves masters (employers)Â and us slaves (employees). If the developers are so important that their work can't be picked up easily by a new person, then start respecting and monetarily recognizing them, if monetary aspect is a problem for a company in present, then give the developer an equity, he will be more than happy in making you succeed rather than just working or changing for salary hikes. If the employers are not even ready for this and still want you to continue than that's a red flag about their intentions, which means they will throw you out and hire a cheaper resource for support once the actual creative software development job is done, to make some extra bucks. Something similar happened in US when outsourcing started to India, and it is repeating itself now when Indian develpers are getting replaced by cheaper options. My suggestion is go for the money until you find someone worthy of your presence in their team.

post_title: Asian cities suck for programmers in terms of real earnings: study
content:
I find this VERY hard to believe for Bangaloreâ€¦US$969 in Bangalore amount to around 60, 000 INRâ€¦which would be just 5000 INR per Month of REALÂ INCOMEâ€¦Even a maid, construction worker, taxi driver, cleaner makes more than that in India anywhere.Â 

I think itâ€™s just another propaganda stats to make look how great America is.

The minimum salary offered anywhere now a days for a decent job is 50, 000 INR..even with all deductions it would still be around 35k, with 2 years experienceâ€¦you can earn 70k to 1 lakh per month inÂ Bangalore to over 2 yrs exp.Â to 5 lakh with 5 years experience in IT

I have worked in US, European, Indian companies and the salary offered in India when you take the cost of living is on pay or just a bit lower than what top developers make in America.Â 

However, down the line..My friends in India who never left India are way more richer than those who are working outside with more number of holidays to spend in Thailand and Philippines ğŸ˜‰

Its amazing, how incredibly less Americans get holidays and work 9 to 12 hours per week..which is not taken into account while the stats were made Plus donâ€™t forget seattle freezeâ€¦How boring, life less Seattle actually isâ€¦Google it ğŸ™‚
excerpt: I find this VERY hard to believe for Bangalore...US$969 in Bangalore amount to around 60, 000 INR...which would be just 5000 INR per Month of REALÂ INCOME...Even a maid, construction worker, taxi driver, cleaner makes more than that in India anywhere.Â I think it's just another propaganda stats to make look how great America is.The minimum salary offered anywhere now a days for a decent job is 50, 000 INR..even with all deductions it would still be around 35k, with 2 years experience...you can earn 70k to 1 lakh per month inÂ Bangalore to over 2 yrs exp.Â to 5 lakh with 5 years experience in ITI have worked in US, European, Indian companies and the salary offered in India when you take the cost of living is on pay or just a bit lower than what top developers make in America.Â However, down the line..My friends in India who never left India are way more richer than those who are working outside with more number of holidays to spend in Thailand and Philippines ;)Its amazing, how incredibly less Americans get holidays and work 9 to 12 hours per week..which is not taken into account while the stats were made Plus don't forget seattle freeze...How boring, life less Seattle actually is...Google it :)

post_title: Discuss: â€˜Get into techâ€™ is the best advice for aspiring entrepreneurs
content:
Whether youâ€™re 18 or 38, you wonâ€™t actually know what itâ€™s like to run a business until you actually do it. Because of that, you will make mistakes. When you do, donâ€™t freak out. Donâ€™t pretend the mistakesÂ didnâ€™t happen. Learn, humbly apologize if necessary,Â and move forward.

IÂ certainly was not ready to start a business at 18. In my industry it takes years to gainÂ the experience and establish the network youâ€™ll need to build a successful company with actual employees working for you. Beyond that, it took several years of experience managing people and managingÂ large projects before IÂ felt comfortable doing it without the safety netÂ a big company provides. To be honest, if youâ€™re 18 and starting a company that will Â employ peopleÂ other than yourself, managing those people will be enormously challenging. Seek mentors who believe in what youâ€™re doing, or find a more experienced co-founder. That will allow you to play to your strengths, while learning how to run a company.
excerpt: Whether you're 18 or 38, you won't actually know what it's like to run a business until you actually do it. Because of that, you will make mistakes. When you do, don't freak out. Don't pretend the mistakesÂ didn't happen. Learn, humbly apologize if necessary,Â and move forward.IÂ certainly was not ready to start a business at 18. In my industry it takes years to gainÂ the experience and establish the network you'll need to build a successful company with actual employees working for you. Beyond that, it took several years of experience managing people and managingÂ large projects before IÂ felt comfortable doing it without the safety netÂ a big company provides. To be honest, if you're 18 and starting a company that will Â employ peopleÂ other than yourself, managing those people will be enormously challenging. Seek mentors who believe in what you're doing, or find a more experienced co-founder. That will allow you to play to your strengths, while learning how to run a company.

post_title: Discuss: â€˜Get into techâ€™ is the best advice for aspiring entrepreneurs
content:
I wonder if there is a clear correlation between being â€œsmartâ€ and success as an entrepreneur. Perhaps a slight above average IQ can be motivated, but anyone who has ever actually started a (real, profitable) businessÂ knows that it truly comes down to long term persistence â€“ which has very little to with how smart one is. Possibly more related to brain chemistry and hormones.

Further, as everything from banking and retail to healthcare is being digitized, the question is if we can even draw a clear line between tech and non-tech industries.

Perhaps today, but less so in a decade.

And I would give one advice:Â Read the Lean Startup, so you donâ€™t spend years building a product that nobody wants. Extremely fundamental, but it was a game changer for me.

Extremely fundamental, but it was a game changer for me.

post_title: Brief: US insurance company forces Singaporean startup to change its logo
content: Companies are obligated to defend their trademarks, and they often do that by hiring the cheapest law firm they can to send out letters to thousands of threatening letters toÂ companies around the world. Â It is just the dead tree version of spam.Â Â The first time I received a letter from an American multinational company threatening to sue me and bankrupt me I was so stressed I could not sleep, but the next day I wrote a nice polite letter back to them explaining why my company name and websites used generic wordsÂ that had been in use for thousands of yearsÂ and there was no way they could possibly own them, and no way a court would enforce their claim. Â The threatening letters stopped, and I never heard from them again. Â Donâ€™t be scared off by these legal spam letters. Â Take the time to properly evaluate whether a court would actually try to enforce their claims before you give in. Â

post_title: Opinion: How ICOs could profoundly impact venture capital
content:
As a way to directly get mass-market investment into a venture, ICO is pretty insane in itâ€™s ease.

However, one of the biggest issues is that people putting money into an ICO are *totally fucked* if the ICO turns out to be a bust/fraud or even if the founders end up just dicking off and failing to create anything meaningful over the proceeding months/years.

Which meansâ€¦ the best way to raise a massive ICO is to pour as much money into marketing and hype as possibleâ€¦ which is bullshit because marketing and hype doesnâ€™t actually make anything worth anythingâ€¦Â 

These ICOs are like kickstarter but *even more* risky. They even tap into unsophisticated investorâ€™s gambling desires considering that owning these coins â€œcouldâ€ (by an idiot with no idea of the actual risks) be considered â€œinvestingâ€ their money into digital currencies.

This is pretty fucking insane to be honest.
excerpt: As a way to directly get mass-market investment into a venture, ICO is pretty insane in it's ease.However, one of the biggest issues is that people putting money into an ICO are *totally fucked* if the ICO turns out to be a bust/fraud or even if the founders end up just dicking off and failing to create anything meaningful over the proceeding months/years.Which means... the best way to raise a massive ICO is to pour as much money into marketing and hype as possible... which is bullshit because marketing and hype doesn't actually make anything worth anything...Â These ICOs are like kickstarter but *even more* risky. They even tap into unsophisticated investor's gambling desires considering that owning these coins "could" (by an idiot with no idea of the actual risks) be considered "investing" their money into digital currencies.This is pretty fucking insane to be honest.

post_title: After Facebook and Google, Chinese tech companies are feeling the heat from censors
content:
In 2013, a bomb killed three people in Boston. Facebook volunteered to help with the investigation and played a vital role in catching the terrorists through their online accounts.Â 

Earlier, in 2009, the terrorist organization ETIM used Facebook to organize a riot that killed 200 Chinese women and children. The Chinese government requested Facebookâ€™s assistance in identifying the terrorists and Facebook refused, but such government intervention is not unique to China.Â 

In 2012, a U.S. Government Executive Order, Assignment of National Security and Emergency Preparedness Communications Functions, gave the President more power to control information than any monarch in history and, since 9/11, the U.S. Government has issued 300,000 national security letters, administrative subpoenas with gag orders that enjoin recipients from ever divulging theyâ€™ve been served.Â

Facebook volunteered to help with the investigation and played a vital role in catching the terrorists through their online accounts.Â Earlier, in 2009, the terrorist organization ETIM used Facebook to organize a riot that killed 200 Chinese women and children. The Chinese government requested Facebookâ€™s assistance in identifying the terrorists and Facebook refused, but such government intervention is not unique to China.Â In 2012, a U.S. Government Executive Order, Assignment of National Security and Emergency Preparedness Communications Functions, gave the President more power to control information than any monarch in history and, since 9/11, the U.S. Government has issued 300,000 national security letters, administrative subpoenas with gag orders that enjoin recipients from ever divulging theyâ€™ve been served.Â

post_title: Discuss: Beware. There is no job guarantee in programming
content:
First of all, I think it will be a gradual process. It wonâ€™t happen overnight. Some application domains will come to be largely automated first, and one by one, others will follow suit. We will see a gradual decline in demand for programmers.

We probably donâ€™t need to worry for another decade or so, but our children and grandchildren will likely face a much different future in IT.

Second, end-users will be empowered to take over more and more of the duties that many programmers assume today. Iâ€™m thinking of plain-vanilla, garden-variety business applications. Even web applications. Many programmers just throw together the content that has been provided to them and glue it together with some coding. The coding they do is not particularly challenging and machine learning software in the future can certainly take care of that.

An end-userÂ will provide the specifications and requirements, as well as some UI design (which can be fairly easy with graphical tools), and a programming â€œbotâ€ can then integrateÂ it altogether. In a sense, the end-user becomes a â€œprogrammerâ€ but without using tools like Java, Python, JavaScript, etc. No special training required.

Third, data science and machine learning are the game changer. We didnâ€™t really have this 20 or 30 years ago; thatâ€™s why weâ€™ve felt smug for so long. But the strides in advancement are absolutely mind-blowing. What people forget (and Iâ€™m including people in our profession) is that technological advancements are accelerating. And accelerating at an alarming rate. What we thought was extremely difficult (or maybe impossible) decades ago, i.e., â€œartificial intelligence,â€ is now easily conceivable.

If youâ€™re betting against this, then youâ€™re a fool.
excerpt: First of all, I think it will be a gradual process. It won't happen overnight. Some application domains will come to be largely automated first, and one by one, others will follow suit. We will see a gradual decline in demand for programmers.We probably don't need to worry for another decade or so, but our children and grandchildren will likely face a much different future in IT.Second, end-users will be empowered to take over more and more of the duties that many programmers assume today. I'm thinking of plain-vanilla, garden-variety business applications. Even web applications. Many programmers just throw together the content that has been provided to them and glue it together with some coding. The coding they do is not particularly challenging and machine learning software in the future can certainly take care of that.An end-userÂ will provide the specifications and requirements, as well as some UI design (which can be fairly easy with graphical tools), and a programming "bot" can then integrateÂ it altogether. In a sense, the end-user becomes a "programmer" but without using tools like Java, Python, JavaScript, etc. No special training required.Third, data science and machine learning are the game changer. We didn't really have this 20 or 30 years ago; that's why we've felt smug for so long. But the strides in advancement are absolutely mind-blowing. What people forget (and I'm including people in our profession) is that technological advancements are accelerating. And accelerating at an alarming rate. What we thought was extremely difficult (or maybe impossible) decades ago, i.e., "artificial intelligence," is now easily conceivable.If you're betting against this, then you're a fool.

post_title: A mental health startup gets over 1000 enquiries in 3 days after mass layoffs in India
content:
Iâ€™m Indian and work in IT..Its about seeing the world as it is and not sugar coating it..The big IT companies used Indians as cheap labour â€¦..hijacked H1b visa, flooded with cheap Indian labor into America and made billions.

People have lostÂ moral compass, when working for big corporationsâ€¦They should have gotten a better deal â€¦like if you fire me..You gotta pay me 100,000 dollarsâ€¦but due to high competition, Indians were themselves ready to work for cheap as long as they have the tag they work in Infosys or Wiproâ€¦and got H1B visasâ€¦and Green cardâ€¦

What were they thinkingâ€¦Corporates work for Bottomline and Profitâ€¦It has always beenâ€¦Profit Before Peopleâ€¦.ALWAYSâ€¦

I work freelance and left the corporate structure long long time back, I earn 50% less than what working in corporations entitlesÂ but Iâ€™m very confidentâ€¦I would never have to be depressed about losing Job, getÂ anxious etc..

Itâ€™s the FEARÂ of losing outâ€¦People in IT should relaxâ€¦Nothing is lostâ€¦Everything will come backâ€¦It has to..like Dot Com bubble..There is a far bigger picture that many are not aware ofâ€¦people will be employed eventually

post_title: Video: Women explain how to address techâ€™s sexual harassment crisis
content:
As much as there is a problem with some really bad behaviours(on both side),Â Interestingly enough and conveniently, ladies have been forgotten as beingÂ part of the initiator dynamics, thereforeÂ avoidingÂ them takingÂ responsibility.

There is aÂ biased one sided view on thisÂ video pointing that only the male gender is responsible of sexual harassment, qualifying all mens as potential sexual harasser and rapist andÂ requesting that we justÂ â€œlisten and believeâ€ you when something supposedly happens to you.

The sad truth is that you ladies get away with a lot and in fact even too much when it comes to take responsibility of your bad behaviour.

You are picturing yourself as victims here, and definitely not helpingÂ the real victims facing this on both side,Â but letâ€™s be honest, you are after the execs seats and ready to do everything to get them and calling out male privileges whenever possibleÂ (white male privileges for the most creative ones) when in fact they haveÂ built industries by taking risks whileÂ you were afraid to loose things and expect to arrive with your bags and get a free pass.

Looking at things, itâ€™s not by having more women in the tech field that this sexual harassment behaviourÂ pointed towards men willÂ stop, but willÂ makeÂ it more difficult to believe you, especially in the rise of recent fake allegations casesÂ made against mens.

Tech conferences and salons are becoming an open platform for you whining(again and again and again) about how mens are bad, they keep theirÂ privileges, ( do you expect Michael Jordan to give you his 6 rings and Championship titles ?),Â how you get no funding when in fact you bring no value in a competitive environment as we have yet to see a real innovation happening beyond an ecommerce/social platform.

And by the way, the tech field need more capable people, man and women, to solve problems before thinking to create wealth as mentioned in one recent articles published here, as it seems itâ€™s the only thing you are after.

Some food for thought:Â https://www.reddit.com/r/AskReâ€¦
